name: Kronos
god_of: God of Earth, Sea, Sky & Time
notes: Castrated his father Ouranos for impregnating his mother Gaia every night when the sky fell to the earth. Ouranos warned him that his children will rise up against him just as he'd done to his father. Terrified of the prophecy coming true he ate his new born children, gobbling them down as soon as his wife Rhea gave birth. Rhea hid her last born, tricking Kronos into eating a black marble stone wrapped in swaddling clothes. This last born child was Zeus who would return and fulfill the prophecy. After defeat by Zeus in the Titan War he was condemned to count to infinity, god of time. Some scholars separate Kronos (Titan) and Chronos (Time). Titan meaning "the striving one", meant as an insult by Ouranos when condenming his son Kronos' ambition when castrating him.

name: Helios
notes: Would become the sun's sole charioteer after Apollo gave up the job when his son Phaeton died trying to drive it. He mocked Phaeton for trying to drive the sun chariot, letting out a high-pitched hysterical squeak when he heard the ridiculous nature of his plan. The same high-pitched squeak that you get when you breathe in the gas named after him, helium.

name: Selene

name: Eos

name: Atlas
god_of: God of Astronomy & Bearer of the Heavens
notes: Zeus' most powerful opponent in the Titan War he was punished to hold up the sky for eternity to separate heaven from earth. He solidified into the Atlas Mountains we call today. Heracles sought his aid during one of his labours to retrieve the Golden Apples of the the Hesperides. As the Hesperides were friends of Atlas he was able to retreive the Apples whilst Heracles held up the sky for him.

name: Epimetheus
notes: Brother of Prometheus. In a different take on the story of Prometheus giving fire to humankind, it is he and his brother that are tasked by the gods of giving each living creature gifts and skills that will help them live their lives. However, when they reach humans, the basket of available gifts is empty. This is when Prometheus decided to steal the arts from Athena and fire from Hephaestus. Mankind could master these to outwit the animals. Thus Prometheus can be seen as the founder of civilisation in a more subtle way than just giving mankind fire.

name: Prometheus
notes: Sided with Zeus in the Titan War. Prometheus means prescience or forethought. He formed the first humans out of clay from Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). Athena would then breathe life into them. Zeus commanded Prometheus to not help them, specifically from teaching them how to make fire, "with fire they could rise up and challenge us" said Zeus. Prometheus lived with the humans but became concerned as to their lack of zest, he decided they needed fire, but not just normal fire, divine fire, which would enflame their sense of imagination and daring. He stole divine fire from Hephaestus's forge on Mount Olympus and taught mankind how to make use of it. Zeus would take his revenge by binding him on the Caucasus Mountains to be pecked at by vultures every day for eternity. As he was immortal he would heal overnight only to be tortured again the next day. He proclaimed that his love for mankind and seeing them flourish thanks to him would be balm for any pain. He would eventually be freed by Heracles and would tell him of his destiny to help the Olympians against the giants. He returned to Zeus and won his forgiveness.

In Dante's Inferno the city of hell is called Dis, another name for Hades. He would be the arbiter for a soul's final destination depending upon how they lived their lives.

name: Amalthea

Zeus accidentally snapped off one of her horns, to compensate he magically filled it with food and drink and it was destined never to be empty. This is the fabled Horn of Plenty known to the Romans as the Cornucopia.

name: Zeus
god_of: King of the Gods, god of sky, weather & fate
notes: Rhea tricked Kronos into eating a piece of magnetite and escaped to Crete to have Zeus. She vowed that he'd take revenge on Kronos. He gives Kronos poison where he regurgitates all 5 children that he ate

name: Calliope
notes: The Muses were the gods of music, song and dance and the source of inspiration to poets. Each muse was assigned a specific artistic influence.

name: Orpheus
notes: The greatest musician of the ancient world. He was rewarded for his bravery in the quest for the Golden Fleece with a wife, Eurydice. One day she was pursued by Aristaeus and she fell into a ditch trying to escape and was bitten by an adder and died. The grief caused Orpheus to stop playing his beautiful music, even the Gods wept. Finally his father Apollo told him to retrieve Eurydice from the underworld with a lyre strung with hairs from his own head. His mellifluous playing won over the hound of hell, Cerberus, and Charon, the ferryman of the dead, which enabled him to enter the palace of Hades itself. Queen of the underworld, Persephone, convinced her husband to let Orpheus play one song and if it moves them they shall release Eurydice. He played the most amazing song that transformed the underworld into a place of light and love. Hades agreed to let Eurydice go but on one condition, that she must follow ten paces behind and if he turns around to look at her, she will be kept in the underworld. He kept the correct pace right until the edge of the underworld, but unbeknownst to him, his last few steps had accelerated into a run, Eurydice, too far behind was still not over the threshold of the underworld when Orpheus looked back in triumph and she was pulled back into the darkness. Orpheus lived out the rest of his life shunning any advances from women eventually sparking the ire of the Ciconians, followers of Dionysus who found his music an affront to their dark dances. They tore him apart in a Bacchic frenzy. His head ended up on the island of Lesbos where it was taken to a cave where people would come from all around to seek guidance and to hear his music once more. Apollo, jealous that the shrine was becoming more popular than his own Delphic oracle, finally silenced him. Finally at peace, his spirit descended to the underworld where he could be with Eurydice at last.

name: Kerberos
notes: Acquired by Hades to guard the underworld. Heracles was ordered to retrieve the dog as the final one of his twelve labours. He ingratiated himself to Persephone, the Queen of the underworld, by taking part in a celebration of her rising back to the heavens. Through this he was able to gain access to Hades where he told him of the need for Cerberus to appease Hera. Hades reluctantly agreed and Heracles was able to wrestle Cerberus into submission and fulfill his final labour.

name: Hydra
notes: A nine-headed serpent, one of which was immortal, which haunted the swamps of Lerna. For every head that was cut off, Hydra grew two more. Each head was capable of spraying jets of deadly poison. Heracles was ordered to pacify her as one of his labours. He managed, with the help of his nephew Iolaus, to slice of the head and cauterise the stump to prevent a new head from forming. He then buried the immortal head deep underground where her poisonous vapors still breathe up their sulphurous gas today by the waters of Lake Lernea. Heracles coated the tips of his arrows with her posionous blood, which would go on to have tragic consequences.

name: Triton
notes: If you see a conch shell, it's probably the mer-man Triton

name: Proteus
notes: Shape shifting Old Man of the Sea

name: Arion
notes: Demeter transformed into a mare to avoid Poseidon, who promptly transformed into a stallian. Arion, the immortal horse with the power of speech was the result of that union.

name: Persephone
god_of: Queen of the underworld, god of Spring
notes: Was kidnapped by Hades in a chariot. This led to a great famine as her mother Demeter neglected her harvest duties to search for her. Helios had witnessed Hades kidnapping her and told Zeus. He demanded the return of Persephone to end the famine. Hades reluctantly agreed but not before feeding her six pomegranate seeds which fated her to return to the underworld for six months of each year. From this we get the seasons, six months of spring and summer growth as Demeter is overjoyed at the return of her daughter, and six months of autumn and winter of Demeter's grieving as Persephone is returned back to the underworld.

name: Hephaestus
god_of: God of  Fire, Blacksmiths, Artisans, Sculptors & Metalworkers
notes: To Hera's dismay, wanting to give birth to the greatest of the gods, saw the child was so ugly that she hurled him down Mount Olympus in disgust. He would forge a golden throne that would bind Hera and come and unlock it to get back to Olympus. He would wed Aphrodite as a reward.

name: Ares
notes: He and Aphrodite would form a couple (Venus and Mars, love and war).

name: Thetis
god_of: God of the sea, leader of the Nereids
notes: Descended from the Oceanids, were the denizens of the deep. Possibly cared for Hephaestus when he was discarded by Hera.

name: Achilles
notes: The mightiest Greek hero of the Trojan war. He argues with the leader of the Greek forces, Agamemnon, who refused to give up Chryseis as his war prize which caused Apollo to send a plague to sweep through the army. When he ordered Agamemnon to release Chryseis, Agamemnon threatened to take his war prize, Briseis, from him in return. He was talked out of killing Agamemnon by Hera, who sent Athena to convince him to give up Briseis in return for later reward. He asked his mother, Thetis, to ask Zeus for the Greek forces to be struck down for their insult to him. Thus the Greeks are almost destroyed by the Trojans until his beloved Patroclus is slain by Hector. Achilles re-enters the conflict swearing revenge and he kills Hector before the walls of Troy, turning the tide of the war in the Greeks favour. He is killed towards the end of the war by Paris, who shot an arrow into his heel.

name: Melisseus
notes: Gifted honey to Zeus and Hera at their wedding. He was rewarded with a sting to defend herself when collecting it, but such a selfish and hubristic demand of the Gods was punished with death if used. Meliss is still the Greek word for honey. A specially blessed honey is given the name Ambrosia, meaning immortality. In fermented, drinkable form, it is called Nectar in honour of the flowers it comes from.

name: Leto
notes: Cursed by Hera, who asked Gaia to not let her give birth on any land as Zeus had cheated on her, she made her way, thanks to Poseidon, to Delos, a floating island in the Cyclades where she would give birth to twins Artemis and Apollo.

name: Athena
notes: Zeus would court Metis, transforming into various creatures to chase her. She hid in a deep cave but Zeus would transform into a snake and coil around her where she would become pregnant. Later she goaded him by transforming into a fly to escape, he transformed into a lizard and ate her (in a shocking Kronos eating his children repeat). Metis then worked inside his head crafting armour and weapons giving Zeus an almighty headache. Hephaestus and Prometheus conjured a plan to fix the pain. They forged an axe that split Zeus' head in two from which Athena emerged. (Zeus' head then healed itself). Athens is named after her after she gifted the city the world's first olive tree. Her signature appearance is with an owl on her shoulder, symbol of watchful wisdom, and the serpent coiled around her feet, symbol of guile, as shown by her father winning over her mother. Like Demeter, she would remain untouched by man. The Greek word for virgin, Parthenos, is often attached to her name, hence the Parthenon, her temple on the Acropolis.

name: Pallas
notes: Childhood friend of Athena, who killed him in an over-energetic playful fight, from then on she would bear his name, Pallas Athena as a token of remorse and sorrow.

name: Artemis
god_of: God of Hunting, wild animals, children, & childbirth
notes: Goddess of chastity and hunting.

name: Apollo
god_of: God of Mathematics, reason, logic, poetry, medicine, knowledge, prophecy, archery & music
notes: He kills a Python sent by Hera to eat him and his sister. The Python came from the landing site of the magnetite stone that Kronos ate thinking it was the infant Zeus. As the Python was born of Gaia and under divine protection he had to be punished by Zeus. He was exiled for eight years to the snake's birthplace beneath Mount Parnassus to replace the snake as guardian of the Omphalos (the spiritual centre of Greece, whose name he would change to Delphi and establish an oracle where anyone could come to ask the god or his appointed priestess, known as a Sibyl or Pythia, questions about the future) and to atone for his crime. Here he would go on to organise The Pythian Games every four years. Apollo was gifted music by Hermes (a tortoise shell with cow guts as strings, the first lyre) as a show of repentence after he stole Apollo's cattle.

name: Hermes
god_of: God of Messengers, thievery, medicine, herds & trade
notes: This infant prodigy gives his name to anything "mercurial". Would become "chief conductor of souls" for the most important human spirits.

name: Human Beings
notes: The first humans were made by Prometheus on Zeus' orders (Metis pulling the strings). He fashioned them from the four elements, Earth (Gaia's clay), Water (Zeus' spittle), Fire (the Sun of Apollo), and Air (the breath of Athena).

name: Pandora
notes: The first mortal female. Pandora was created by the Gods as part of Zeus's cunning plan to punish mankind and Prometheus for stealing divine fire. She was bestowed with a gift presented by Zeus himself, a container filled with secrets which she was ordered never to open. She would marry Epimetheus, Prometheus's brother. Unable to resist temptation she eventually opened the container releasing illness, violence, deceit, misery, and want upon the world, bringing an end to the Golden Age.

Zeus had intended hope to be released to forever torment mankind that there were better things to come. Inside the box, we were free to live without any aspirations or illusions of hope.

notes: Pyrrha and her husband Deucalion survived the great flood and would go on to repopulate a new race. After consulting Themis at Delphi they were instructed to throw rocks down Mount Parnassus from which sprang a new race out of the ground (mother Earth, Gaia).

name: Deucalion
notes: His mother was either Clymene or Hesione. Pyrrha and her husband Deucalion survived the great flood and would go on to repopulate a new race. After consulting Themis at Delphi they were instructed to throw rocks down Mount Parnassus from which sprang a new race out of the ground (mother Earth, Gaia).

name: Hesione
notes: Wife of Prometheus and minor god of foresight.

name: Lycaon
notes: One of the first human rulers, Lycaon, King of Arcadia was son of the Pelsagos who had been one of the original clay figures formed by Prometheus. He killed his own son Nyctimus as an offering to the gods. Zeus was so revolted he brought the boy back to life and turned Lycaon into a wolf. However, Nyctimus's brothers ravaged the land so Zeus brought about massive floods to drown the whole of Greece and the Mediterranean, all, save Deucalion and Pyrrha, who thanks to Prometheus's foresight, survived aboard a wooden chest.

name: Nyctimus
notes: nan

name: Human Beings 2.0
notes: True civilisation could now begin as men and women were now created equally. These humans were now mortal thanks to the demons that escaped from Pandora's box.

name: Minos I
notes: Upon their deaths they were appointed Judges of the Underworld, taking over from Hades as arbiters of a soul's final destination. The righteous would end up at Elysian Fields (Isles of the Blessed). The vast majority were placed in the Meadows of Asphodel. The sinners were placed in the Fields of Punishment in the depths of Tartarus to be tortured for eternity.

name: Europa
notes: One day whilst playing she discovered a beautiful white bull, taking it by the horns it flew her over the lands west of her parent's kingdown of Tyre in modern day Lebanon, towards the Greek islands (the journey was so remarkable that the landmass she flew over is named after her in honour, Europe). The bull was none other than Zeus. Europa finally settled on Crete bearing Zeus three children, Minos, Rhadamanthus, and Sarpedon.

name: Sisyphus
notes: Horrible, nasty Sisyphus. He despised his brother, Salmoneus, more than anything. He married his brother's daughter, Tyro, because the Delphic Oracle told him that the result of that union would bring his brother down. This was foiled when his wife discovered the plan, took revenge by drowning their two children, and fled back to her father. He angered the gods so much that Zeus personally sent Thanatos to take him to the underworld. However, proud of his cunning, he tricked Thanatos into handcuffing himself by mocking his shackles and saying that they wouldn't work. He then kept Thanatos prisoner in his wardrobe. Knowing that without death, the gods would be on his tail sooner or later, he made a pact with his new wife to not make offerings to the gods when he did eventually die so that he couldn't cross the River Styx. When Thanatos was finally rescued he came for him again and took him to the underworld. When he couldn't cross the Styx he swam across, looking the worse for wear on the other side he spoke with Persephone, Queen of the underworld, and told her that his appearance was due to his wife's neglect in not making offerings to the gods to enable his passage. A shocked Persephone wanted to punish his wife, but Sisyphus tricked her into sending him back to life to take revenge on her in person. They would go on to live happily ever after. When his wife died and Persephone's decree finally expired, Thanatos came for him a third time, but this time Hermes offered him a deal, in cheating death twice you have earned a chance at immortality. All you have to do is push this boulder up the slope and out of the opening at the top to attain immortality, or, you can go to Elysium and live a happy afterlife. Sisyphus thought that the task was possible so that's what he chose. He is still there to this day, in the halls of Tartarus, pushing the boulder up the hill only to fail and see it come crashing down again.

name: Aeolus
notes: King of Aeolia, later called Thessaly.

name: Tantalus
notes: Ruler of the kingdom of Lydia, modern day Anatolia in Turkey, he grew immensely rich from local mineral deposits. He abused Zeus's hospitality (one of the most serious offences in the eyes of the gods) by stealing ambrosia and nectar from Olympus. He offered to put on a feast to appease the gods as this was the time of Demeter's search for her daughter Persephone, a time of famine across the Earth. In a cruel twist, Tantalus offered his own son, Pelops, as part of the feast. Demeter took a bite from his shoulder and noticed there was something amiss. Zeus understood and summoned Clotho, the spinner, to put the body parts back together. Demeter had Hephaestus carve him a new shoulder from ivory and Zeus reanimated him. Tantalus was dispatched straight to Tartarus and cursed for eternity to have a bough of a tree laden with luscious fruits dangle above his head, just out of reach, and a pool of water up to his waist that would sink when he tried to drink from it. He could not move away as above him hovered a great stone that threatened to crush him if he did (this stone material would later be named tanatlum). There Tantalus stands to this day, plagued by thirst and hunger, yet so close to food and water, yet cannot quite reach them, so tantalisingly close (also named after him).

name: Eurynomos
notes: A hideous demon who would meet the dead sinners and strip the flesh from their bones.

name: Hecate
god_of: God of Potions, keys, ghosts, poisons & witchcraft
notes: Helped Demeter search for her daughter Persephone when she was captured by Hades.

name: Perses
notes: nan

name: Asteria
god_of: God of Shooting Stars & Night-time Divinations
notes: Tried to escape Zeus's overtures by turning into a quail.

name: Pan
notes: Comforted Psyche when she defied Eros to sneak a look at him. He told her not to commit suicide but to take revenge on her sisters who had tricked her into looking at Eros.

name: Dryope
notes: nan

name: Hermaphroditus
notes: Fathered by Hermes and Aphrodite, hence the name. Was wooed by the nymph Salmacis who proclaimed to the gods that they should never be parted. The gods duly obliged and they did indeed become one, fusing into a single body. One body, two sexes.

name: Salmacis
notes: Courted Hermaphroditus, she proclaimed to the gods that they should never be parted. The gods duly obliged and they did indeed become one, fusing into a single body. One body, two sexes.

name: Anteros
notes: The Greeks untangled love's complexity by naming each strand and providing divinities to represent them. These are the Erotes, a retinue of winged godlings that accompany the supreme goddess of love and beauty Aphrodite.

name: Silenus
notes: Fathered by Hermes and an unknown nymph, Silenus was a snub-nosed, donkey-tailed lecher who would grow up to become a bearded, pot-bellied old drunk. A popular subject in paintings and sculptures.

name: Eros
notes: Fell in love with Psyche after a botched Cupid's arrow attempt. When Psyche's parents consulted the Oracle at Delphi as to why Psyche hadn't yet married, they were ordered to give her up to one of the Gods or else their subjects would live on in misery. They duly obliged and the God that took her away was none other than Eros. When he was defied by Psyche when she snook a look at him he fell into a great sadness. Couples were no longer getting together which Aphrodite noticed and found out that her original plan to punish Psyche had backfired so badly. She would punish Psyche to carry out impossible tasks. When Eros found out he pleaded with Zeus who showed Aphrodite that she was still God of all beauty. She relented and Zeus immortalised Psyche by giving her ambrosia from his cup. They would go on to wed.

name: Hedylogos
god_of: God of The Language of love
notes: The Erotes were the winged gods of love.

name: Himeros
notes: The Erotes were the winged gods of love.

name: Hymenaios
notes: The Erotes were the winged gods of love.

name: Pothos
god_of: God of Love for the Absent & Departed
notes: The Erotes were the winged gods of love.

name: Aristides
notes: nan

name: Damaris
notes: nan

name: Calanthe
notes: Jealous of her sister Psyche for finding love with Eros, she tricked her into defying his demand not to see him and whilst he slept she snook a look at him in lamplight. Examining one of his arrows she cut herself and consequently fell deeply in love with Eros in return as he had for her. Unhappy at this defiance Eros departed and Psyche lost everything. Psyche eventually got her revenge by tricking her that it was her that Eros desired all along, not Psyche. Instructing her to to the top of a mountain to let Zephyrus take her to Eros, the west wind didn't appear and she fell to her death on the rocks below.

name: Zona
notes: Jealous of her sister Psyche for finding love with Eros, she tricked her into defying his demand not to see him and whilst he slept she snook a look at him in lamplight. Examining one of his arrows she cut herself and consequently fell deeply in love with Eros in return as he had for her. Unhappy at this defiance Eros departed and Psyche lost everything. Psyche eventually got her revenge by tricking her that it was her that Eros desired all along, not Psyche. Instructing her to to the top of a mountain to let Zephyrus take her to Eros, the west wind didn't appear and she fell to her death on the rocks below.

name: Psyche
notes: Was of such beauty that people abandoned the cult of Aphrodite to worship her. In her vengeance she ordered her son Eros to strike her with his arrow and make sure the first thing she sees is the foulest smelling pig you can find. However, in a botched cupid attempt he scratched himself with his own arrow as the pig squealed, Psyche awoke, Eros saw Psyche and fell deeply in love with her. His love for her was so complete that he couldn't bear to trick her so he left. Psyche was non the wiser and went back to sleep. She would eventually end up with Eros but agreed to his demand that she could never see him in person. Tricked by her sisters into looking at Eros she lost everything. She would exact revenge, see Zona and Calanthe.

name: Zephyrus
notes: Transported Psyche to Eros.

name: Hedone
notes: nan

name: Inachus
notes: One of the very earliest rulers in Greece. He was the first King of Argos in the Peloponnese peninsula.

name: Melia
notes: nan

name: Io
notes: The first human to attract the attention of Zeus. He transformed her into a hiefer to escape the attention of Hera but Hera's keen eye spotting this straight away. She ordered Argus, Io's nephew to watch over her. Zeus then got Hermes to help him distract Argus, which he did by killing him, the Gods were capable of great cruelty. Io was set free but Hera, who witnessed the whole episode, sent a gadfly to sting her repeatedly. She galloped away in pain, far from Zeus's reach across Greece into Turkey (the river Bosporus being named after her, which translates as the cow crossing) ending at the Caucasas mountains where Prometheus comforted her that things will get better and she would eventually return to human form.

name: Mycene
notes: nan

name: Arestor
notes: nan

name: Argus
notes: Argus, son of Mycene and Arestor was commanded by Hera to watch over Io after she was transformed into a heifer by Zeus who wanted his wicked way with her. His nickname was Panoptes, the all-seeing. His 100 eyes made him well suited to the task. Hermes, on Zeus's orders, played music to him to fall asleep on his watch and stabbed him in the heart. Devestated by the death of her loyal subject, Hera took Argus's hundred bright eyes and fixed them onto the tail of an old fowl, transforming it into a peacock.

name: Epaphus
notes: Cruelly taunted his friend Phaeton which led to his death when he tried to drive the sun chariot in a doomed attempt to show off.

name: Keroessa
notes: nan

name: Byzas
notes: Founder of the city of Byzantium.

name: Erechtheus
notes: Hephaestus, after helping to bring Athena into the world by splitting open Zeus's head, became infatuated with her. One day, unable to control himself he tried to force himself on her, managing in his excitement to spill his seed on her. Athena removed her headband, wiped up the mess and threw it down the mountain. This landed on the ground and made Gaia pregnant, from which Erechtheus was born. Athena deemed that he should be immortal and he would grow up to be the legendary founder of Athens, Erechthonius.

name: Herse
notes: Charged by Athena with looking after Erechtheus, the future founder of Athens, she was shocked to find him kept company by a snake in his basket. This was Athena's doing to endow immortality upon him (all snakes were sacred to Athena) and promptly threw herself off the Acropolis.

name: Aglauros
notes: Charged by Athena with looking after Erechtheus, the future founder of Athens, she was shocked to find him kept company by a snake in his basket. This was Athena's doing to endow immortality upon him (all snakes were sacred to Athena) and promptly threw herself off the Acropolis.

name: Pandrosos
notes: Charged by Athena with looking after Erechtheus, the future founder of Athens, she, unlike her sisters Herse and Agluaros, didn't disobey Athena's orders into looking inside Erechtheus's basket, and consequently, didn't commit suicide by jumping off the Acropolis.

name: Phaeton
notes: Son of Apollo who he never saw, he was raised by the human Merops. One day, tired of the boasting of his friend Epaphus about his father Zeus, he lied that his father was going to let him drive the sun chariots across the sky. After pleading with Apollo he was given permission. During the drive he tried to fly down to show off to Epaphus but lost control scorching the Earth in the area of Africa now known as the Sahara Desert but to Greeks as the place that Phaeton scorched. Losing all control he then shot up too high plunging Earth into darkness and a big freeze. The Gods complained to Zeus who struck Phaeton down with a thunderbolt to bring the situation, and Earth, back under control but not before the Earth had newly acquired ice caps and deserts as a result. Apollo took Phaeton's death hard and vowed never again to ride the sun chariot, passing on this duty to Helios. A tragic parable on lies getting out of hand, his epitaph reads, "Here Phaeton lies who in the sun-god's chariot fated. And though greatly he failed, more greatly he dared."

name: Merops
notes: Step-father to Phaeton.

name: Cygnus
notes: Friend and lover of Phaeton. Was so distraught when Phaeton died trying to drive the sun chariot that he would let out a horrific wail. Apollo, Phaeton's father, was so distraught at this that he turned him into a beautiful swan out of pity, fated to live in silence until his own death when he would let out a melancholic goodbye, his swan song. In honour of Cygnus all young swans are of course called cygnets.

name: Memphis
notes: nan

name: Libya
notes: nan

name: Aegyptus
notes: Great-grandson of Epaphus, he would go on to rule Egypt for generations.

name: Agenor
notes: King of Tyre, modern day Lebanon.

name: Telephassa
notes: Queen of Tyre, modern day Lebanon.

name: Nephele
notes: Zeus, angered by Ixion who tried to seduce Hera, sent Nephele to Ixion with the appearance of Hera as a trap. He coupled with her incurring Zeus's wrath in the process who bound him to a burning wheel in the depths of Tartarus for eternity. The result of this coupling was a son, Centauros.

name: Cadmus
notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He met his future wife Harmony on his quest. Consulting the Delphic Oracle he was told to give up the search and instead follow a heifer marked with a half moon. Where it drops, there you must build. Later he would be told to enter the Phocian Games where he would win a cow which, lo and behold, had a half moon shaped mark on its back. He followed the cow to a place where the Ismenian Dragon, sacred to the god of war, Ares, was. He bravely killed the dragon but made a mighty enemy in the process. Athena came to his and Harmony's aid and ordered them to plant the teeth from which sprouted soldiers, which he called Spartoi. He built the city of Thebes on this site and the Spartoi would be his lords. Ares, not to be outdone, would plague Cadmus's happiness from then on, eventually wearing him down so much he begged for it to come to an end. Ares duly obliged turning him into a snake. Athena took pity on Harmony and turned her into a snake also. The couple would go on to live together in a temple sacred to Athena.

name: Cilix
notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He abandoned the quest and returned to Asia Minor to establish his own kingdom, Cilicia.

name: Phoenix
notes: Not to be confused with the mythical bird, Phoenicia would succeed his father Agenor as ruler of Tyre and name it Phoenicia after himself. All of this after he abandoned his quest to find his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete.

name: Thasos
notes: Charged with rescuing his sister Europa who had ridden off on a bull (Zeus) to Crete. He abandoned the quest and settled on the island of Thasos.

name: Electra
notes: nan

name: Agamemnon
notes: King of Mycenae and leader of the Greek forces in the Trojan war. He took Chryseis as a war prize and refused to give her up when her father, Chryses, tried to ransom her. This angered Apollo (Chryses was a priest of Apollo) who sent a plague sweeping through the Greek armies. Agamemnon was forced to release Chryseis to end it. A fierce argument broke out when Achilles tried to convince him to give up Chryseis. Agamemnon ordered Achilles' war prize, Briseis, to be given to him in recompense. This caused Achilles to remove himself from the conflict which weakened the Greeks and nearly led to their destruction until Achilles' beloved Patroclus was killed by Hector, causing Achilles to re-enter the battle and turn the tide back in their favour. Upon his return from Troy he was killed by Aegisthus, the lover of his wife Clytemnestra.

name: Clytemnestra
notes: Wife of Agamemnon, King of Mycenae and leader of the Greek forces during the Trojan war. She murders him upon his eventual return home, conspiring with her lover, Aegisthus, to have him killed.

name: Electra
notes: nan

name: Dardanus
notes: Gave his name to the Dardanelles, site of the ill-fated Gallipoli landings in the First World War.

name: Iasion
notes: An agricultural hero and the sprintime consort of Demeter, god of the harvest.

name: Harmonia
notes: Wife of Cadmus, Prince of Tyre and King of Thebes. When he was finally worn down by Ares for killing the Ismenian Dragon and turned into a snake, Athena turned her into a snake also so they could live out their days together.

name: Pelagon
notes: King of Phocis. Died in the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

name: Amphidamas
notes: Father of Pelagon, King of Phocis. He dreamed that Cadmus would enter and win the Phocian games to win the "greatest prize the world has ever seen". See Cadmus for more information.

name: Echion
notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted.

name: Udaeus
notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted.

name: Chthonius
notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted. In fact, Chthonius gives his name to chthonic beings, which translates as "from the earth".

name: Hyperenor
notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted.

name: Pelor
notes: Cadmus, after slaying the Ismenian Dragon, planted the teeth to assuage the wrath of Ares whose guardian it was. From which sprouted the Spartoi of which five survived to become the founding Lords of Thebes, named after the place where they sprouted.

name: Asopos
notes: River God from the area of Thebes.

name: Antiope
notes: Daughter of either Asopos the river god, or King Nycteus, one of the original Theban Spartoi.

name: Amphion
notes: One of the co-founders of Thebes with Cadmus and Zethus. His wife Niobe would anger the mother of the gods Leto which brought Artemis and Apollo to hunt down and kill their fourteen children. When he heard news of the slaughter he took his own life by falling on his sword.

name: Zethus
notes: One of the co-founders of Thebes with Cadmus and Amphion.

name: Polydorus
notes: nan

name: Illyrius
notes: nan

name: Agave
notes: Was torn to pieces by her sisters, her son Pentheus also died with her, for their failure to honour the god Dionysus.

name: Autono√´
notes: nan

name: Ino
notes: She suckled her sister Semele's child by Zeus (the infant Dionysus). Married King Athamas of Boetia. She wanted her own children and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle to take the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and claimed that only the sacrifice of Phrixus would end it (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to die with him). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent a golden ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. Athamas eventually discovered her wicked plot and killed her son Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. He cornered Ino and her other child, Melicertes and they threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his step-mother, transformed her into the immortal Leucothea, the 'white-goddess' of the sea.

name: Semele
notes: A lover of Zeus. Upon Hera discovering yet another affair, she tricked Semele into doubting if it really was Zeus she was in love with, and that she should find out for sure by asking him to show himself in his true form. He duly obliged transforming into the mightiest and brightest thundercloud that struck Semele dead. Upon hearing Hera's wicked, vengeful laugh, Zeus rescued their unborn child from Semele's womb and kept it safe in his thigh. This child would be born Dionysus.

name: Pentheus
notes: King of Thebes after Cadmus and Harmonia departed. Was torn to pieces by his mother's sisters for their failure to venerate Dionysus.

name: Bero√´
god_of: Nurse of the gods, god of the city of Beirut
notes: Gave her name to the city of Beirut.

name: Dionysus
notes: Produced the world's first vintage from his lover and friend Ampelos (vine in Greek). Replaced Hestia in the quorum of twelve Olympians after she retired. The Gods were happy to have Dionysus for his wine and debauchery, all except Hera, as Dionysus was the result of Zeus's affair with Semele. Hera swore never to drink from Dionysus's cup and would later curse his son Priapus with ugliness and impotence.

name: Chiron
notes: Possibly taught Dionysus how to make wine from grapes.

name: Ampelos
notes: Dionysus was so besotted with Ampelos that he would let him win all games between them. Ampelos would become spoiled as a result and once boasted that he rode his wild bull better than Selene, the goddess of the moon. Selene struck him down causing the bull to trample and gore Ampelos. Dionysus could not save him but instead watched his corpse transform magically into a winding, climbing plant replete with drops of blood which solidified into berries. He had become a vine from which Dionysus would produce the world's first wine.

name: Staphylos
notes: King of Assyria, he gave a banquet in Dionysus's honour and promptly died of the world's first hangover. In his honour Dionysus named bunches of grapes after him, staphylos.

name: Methe
notes: Queen of Assyria, her husband Staphylos died after a banquet with Dionysus from a hangover. Dionysus named alcholic liquid and drunkenness after her in compensation, methe.

name: Botrys
notes: Son of the King and Queen of Assyria, his father, Staphylos, died after a banquet with Dionysus from a hangover. Dionysus named the grape after him in compensation, botrys.

name: Priapus
god_of: God of Phalluses, Male Genitalia & Vegetable Gardens
notes: Cursed by Hera as he was the son of Dionysus, who was the result of an affair by Zeus. She cursed him with ugliness and impotence and had him cast from Olympus. Priapus is the god of male genitalia, cursed to wander in a state of excitement which would fail him when he tried to do anything about it. The irony that his father is the god of alcohol is not lost on the gods, the gift to the world that 'provokes desire but takes away the performance'.

name: Aristaeus
god_of: God of Cheesemaking, Beekeeping, Hunting & Olive-growing
notes: Minor deity of bee-keeping, agriculture and other country crafts. He pursued Orpheus' wife, Eurydice. She ran away and fell into a ditch where she was bitten by an adder and killed. Thus began the hero Orpheus' quest to retrieve her from the underworld.

name: Actaeon
notes: Stumbled upon Artemis bathing in a lake whilst out hunting. She, the goddess of chastity, couldn't bear anyone to see her naked so she ordered him to never speak another word. He duly forgot and was turned into a stag by Artemis. Actaeon's original hunting party then caught up with him and killed him.

name: Erysichthon
notes: King of Thessaly. He angered Demeter, the goddess of the harvest, by chopping down a sacred tree. Demeter sent Limos, one of the monsters released from Pandora's jar to curse him. Limos was a demon of famine and starvation and cursed Erysichthon with constant, unsatiated hunger. He was reduced to selling his daughter Mestra to raise money to try and appease his impossibe appetite. Eventually he ate himself and Demter was avenged.

name: Mestra
notes: Mestra, daughter of Erysicthon, King of Thessaly, was a former lover of Poseidon, who had rewarded her with the ability to alter her shape at will. She used this gift to help her father who had been cursed by Demeter and Limos, the demon of famine and starvation, to being in a state of constant hunger. She would be sold to a suitor so her father could raise money to appease his insatiable hunger, transform into one animal or another and escape, ready to be sold again.

name: Coronis
notes: Princess of Phlegyantis, she was a lover of Apollo, but whilst pregnant with his child she cheated on him with a mortal, Ischys. One of Apollo's white crows witnessed the affair and reported back to Apollo. Apollo asked his sister Artemis to enact revenge on the kingdom for this betrayal. The crow informed Apollo that Coronis lay dying but she didn't ask for forgiveness, only to save their child. The crow crowed once too many times and Apollo lost his temper and turned it black, all crows have been that colour ever since. Apollo did save the baby, who would be called Asclepius.

name: Ischys
notes: Lover of Coronis who cheated on Apollo whilst pregnant with his child.

name: Asclepius
notes: Son of Apollo and Coronis, who was avenged for having an affair whilst pregnant with Asclepius but the baby was saved from her womb by Apollo. He was raised by Chiron who nurtured his precocious talent of medicine and healing. Once he healed a bruised snake with a potion of his own making. This pleased Athena, to whom snakes were sacred, and the snake whispered into Asclepius's ear the many secrets of healing and medicine. To this day, many ambulances and clinics can be seen with an emblem bearing a wooden staff (staff of Ascelpius) entwined with a serpent. Athena also presented a jar of Gorgon's blood as a reward. This famed liquid that keeps the gods immortal, is deadly to humans, but can bring the dead back to life. Later in life, unable to resist temptation, Asclepius started to use the blood on his patients. This angered Hades who complained that there were no more dead being delivered to him. Zeus agreed and struck Asclepius dead with a bolt of thunder. This angered Apollo, his father, so much that he struck the cyclopes Brontes, Steropes, and Arges dead (it was the cyclopes that manufactured Zeus's thunderbolts). Such rebelliousness was punished by Zeus and Apollo was commanded to serve the Thessalian King Admetus in a lowly position for one whole year.

name: Epione
notes: Her name means 'soothing', or 'relief from pain'. She married Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing.

name: Hygieia
notes: Daughter of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. She was trained in the practices of cleanliness, diet and physical exercise that are today named 'hygiene' after her.

name: Panacea
notes: Daughter of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. She was taught the arts of medicines that could cure anything, which is what her name means, 'cure all'.

name: Aceso
notes: Daughter of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. She was taught the healing process itself, what we now know as immunology.

name: Iaso
notes: Daughter of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. She was taught recovery and recuperation.

name: Machaon
notes: Son of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. He would become the prototypical army medic, serving in the Trojan War and recorded by Homer.

name: Podalirius
notes: Son of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. He would become the prototypical army medic, serving in the Trojan War and recorded by Homer.

name: Telesphorus
notes: Son of Asclepius, the master of medicine and healing. He was taught rehabilitation and convalesence by his father.

name: Admetus
notes: Thessalian King, he had won the approval of Zeus for his exceptionally warm hospitality. When Apollo was punished for killing the cyclopes that helped kill his son Asclepius, he was sent to Admetus to serve under him for one whole year. The two became great friends, again due to his warm hospitality. Apollo made a deal with the Moirai to make him immortal, he just had to find someone to die in his place. His loving wife Alcestis agreed to die for him. Filled with remorse, he tried to stop her, but the will of the Moirai could not be overturned. It was at her funeral that Heracles arrived to stay with Admetus. Finding out about the tragic events, he promised to rescue Alcestis from the underworld. He found Thanatos, the god of death at her tomb and wrestled him to the ground, rescuing Alcestis and taking her back to Admetus.

name: Ixion
notes: Ixion, already angering the gods to breaking point by refusing one of their most strongly held beliefs, the spirit of hospitality, or xenia, and by killing his father-in-law, Deioneus, King of Phocis and committing the first blood murder, would go on to anger them even further. Invited to a banquet by Zeus he tried it on with his wife, Hera. An angry Zeus then tested him the day after by animating a cloud shaped Hera look-a-like and presenting it to Ixion. He duly impregnated her. This was the final straw and Zeus bound him to a wheel of fire and sent him down to the depths of Tartarus where he revolves, spread-eagled and roasting in agony to this day. "Thou art a soul in bliss,but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead." King Lear.

name: Dia
notes: Wife of Ixion, the King of Lapiths and daughter of Deioneus, King of Phocis. Ixion angered the gods when he refused to pay the dowry for Dia to Deioneus.

name: Deioneus
notes: King of Phocis. His daughter, Dia, was married to Ixion, the King of Lapiths. When Ixion refused to pay the agreed bride-price for his daughter, he took revenge but was thrown into a fiery pit by Ixion.

name: Centauros
notes: His father Ixion had angered Zeus by sleeping with Nephele thinking it was Hera, Zeus's wife. Centauros was the result of Nephele's and Ixion's liasion. An ugly and misshapen boy he turned his back on humans and instead roamed with the wild mares of Mount Pelion. The result was a progeny of untameable and savage animals, part man, part horse named after him, Centaurs.

name: Phylira
notes: Lover of Kronos, she tried to rebut his advances but he transformed into a mighty stallion and took her against her will. The great Centaur, Chiron was the offspring of this union.

name: Iphimedia
notes: Lover of Poseidon she bore him twin sons, Otus and Ephialtes.

name: Otus
notes: Giants in every sense of the word, Otus and his twin Ephialtes were instructed by their father Poseidon to test heaven by building their own mountain. Zeus heard about this devious plan to challenge his authority and he sent Apollo to fell them with arrows. Their punishment in the underworld was to be bound to pillars with writhing snakes.

name: Ephialtes
notes: Giants in every sense of the word, Otus and his twin Ephialtes were instructed by their father Poseidon to test heaven by building their own mountain. Zeus heard about this devious plan to challenge his authority and he sent Apollo to fell them with arrows. Their punishment in the underworld was to be bound to pillars with writhing snakes.

name: Athamas
notes: Boeotian king married to the cloud nymph Nephele of Hera doppelg√§nger fame.

name: Phrixus
notes: His cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice Phrixus (his sister Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar.

name: Helle
notes: Her cruel step-mother Ino, wanted her own children to inherit the throne of Boetia so she contrived a famine and informed her husband King Athamas that the only way to end it was to sacrifice her brother Phrixus (Helle wouldn't be parted and agreed to be sacrificed alongside). When their mother Nephele heard about this she sent the Golden Ram to rescue them from the sacrifical altar. A gust of wind caused Helle to fall from the ram and she plummeted to hear death in the sea below. The Greeks call this spot 'the Hellespont, or Sea of Helle' in her honour (now known as the Dardanelles).

name: Dione
notes: nan

name: Pelops
notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. Murdered by his father and offered to the gods during a feast. The gods were so angered they dispatched Tantalus to Tartarus for eternity and brought Pelops back to life, endowing him with a new shoulder made of ivory to replace the one that was mistakenly eaten. He took in Laius as a baby who was smuggled out of Thebes when his father, Labdacus was overthrown. Laius took Pelops' son, Chrysippus with him when he finally returned to Thebes to reclaim his throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship so Chrysippus took his own life. Pelops swore a curse on Laius and his line for ever.

name: Niobe
notes: Angered Leto, the titaness and mother of the gods by comparing her own motherhood to hers. She claimed a real mother would raise more than two children, she herself had managed fourteen. When Leto heard about this her children Artemis and Apollo went straight to Thebes and hunted down every one of Noibe's fourteen children and wiped them out. Her grief was uncontollable. The gods themselves couldn't even bear her unending lamentations and turned her to stone. But not even solid stone could hold the tears back. Even now, visitors to the place she was turned to stone, Mount Spil, can see the rock formation bears her resemblance and the gushing waters that flow from it.

name: Broteas
notes: nan

name: Salmoneus
notes: Brother of Sisyphus whom he hated with a passion. Angered Zeus by claiming to be able to summon thunderstorms, Zeus duly struck him down and killed him.

name: Cretheus
notes: Ruler of Iolcos, a city in the north west Greek mainland. His death caused a power struggle because his son Aeson was the rightful heir, but Aeson's half-brothers, Pelias and Neleus, believed the throne should be theirs.

name: Tyro
notes: Wife of Sisyphus and daughter of his brother Salmoneus (yes, he married his niece). Sisyphus only married her because the Delphic Oracle told Sisyphus that "Sons of Sisyphus and Tyro rise to slay Salmoneus". Salmoneus was his brother whom he despised more than anything. One day Tyro found out the real reason for their marriage. Feeling a stronger attachment to her father rather than her husband, she drowned their children in the river before fleeing back to her father.

name: Melops
notes: Friend of Sisyphus.

name: Autolycus
notes: Neighbour of Sisyphus. He got caught stealing Sisyphus's cattle.

name: Amphithea
notes: nan

name: Anticlea
notes: She married Laertes and gave birth to the famous hero Odysseus. Some suggest Odysseus was the son of Sisyphus, not Laertes, as Sisyphus trapped her father Autolycus stealing his cattle and would probably have sought revenge by violating her.  In one of the most famous passages of the Odyssey, Odysseus makes a trip to the underworld to seek advice on how to get home. He encounters the spirit of his mother, unable to accept her death he initially rebuffs her. He finally allows her to come forward where he learns that she died of grief, longing for the return of her only son.

name: Laertes
notes: Father of the legendary hero Odysseus. He retreats to his farm during Odysseus' long absence from home, overcome with grief. When Odysseus finally gets home he hides his identity at first, but seeing how distraught his father is he reveals his true identity bringing an end to the journey. Laertes then aids Odysseus in killing the suitors of his wife, Penelope.

name: Odysseus
notes: Legendary hero and king of Ithaca. He was renowned for his intellect and guile, it is his idea to storm Troy inside the Trojan Horse. He takes part in the Trojan war and his ten-year journey home from the conflict is famously retold in Homer's poem, The Odyssey.

name: Aegina
notes: Was beautiful enough to catch Zeus's eye who swept her away to an island off the coast of Attica. Her father Asopos sought her everywhere. Sisyphus grassed Zeus in to him who went on a doomed quest to retrieve her.

name: Tmolus
notes: nan

name: Nycteus
notes: One of the original Theban Spartoi who sprouted from the dragon's teeth.

name: Heracles
notes: Born Alcides, son of Zeus and Alcmene. Zeus had wanted a child in the blood line of Perseus as Hera had prophecised that a child of Perseus would save the Olympians. Hera was so incensed at yet another affair of Zeus that she swore eternal enmity against Alcides. Alcmene sought advice from the oracle Tiresias who told her that "Alcides will do marvellous things, slay terrible monsters and topple tyrants, but Hera will hound him without mercy. To placate her, you could try changing his name perhaps... how about Hera's pride?" From then on Alcides would be known as Heracles. Blessed with immense strength, courage and power, he was also cursed with a short fuse. One fateful day he was confronted by a demon and two dragons which he duly killed, but when he looked at the corpses it was in fact his wife Megara and their two children. It was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions. She had stripped Heracles of everthing, his family and reputation. Not knowing how to atone he sought guidance at Delphi. He was instructed, via Hera, to report to Eurystheus, King of Mycenae, who owed his throne to Hera as she had induced his birth before Heracles and thus denied him the throne. He was ordered to serve the King for ten years, and he must do whatever the King asks of him. He completed twelve labours, ordered by Eurystheus and was finally freed and granted immortality for completing his penance. He thus regained his heroic status. He would go on to fight in the Gigantomachy and save the Olympians from the Gigantes. For this Hera's hatred turned into grateful loveand she lifted the curse upon him. In later life he encountered Nessus, a centaur whose family and friends Heracles had killed in one of his tantrums. Nessus tried to molest his wife Deianira and Heracles shot him down with his Hydra poisoned arrows. Nessus tricked Deianira to give the shirt he was wearing to Heracles if ever their marriage was in trouble. Later on she did gift him the shirt, thinking it was charmed. The poison took hold and killed Heracles in the most agonising way, Deianira killed herself as a result. Achieving immortality for his labours, Zeus raised him to the firmament as the constellation Hercules.

name: Marsyas
notes: A satyr, a follower of Dionysus he found Athena's aulos, a woodwind instrument that she had discarded from Olympus because she couldn't get a good enough sound from it. He mastered the instrument and in a foolish moment of hubris he challenged the god of the lyre, Apollo, to a competition. Apollo, obviously, won the contest and punished Marsyas by flaying the skin right off him (the gods hated hubris although some scholars suggest it was his hide that he removed and not his actual skin) but the 'Flaying of Marsyas' would become a favourite subject of painters, poets and sculptors from then on. A parable on the impossibility of outdoing the divine.

name: Idmon
notes: nan

name: Arachne
notes: Dared to compare her talent for weaving to that of the goddess Athena. Athena challenged her to a weave-off. Athena went first and made a tapestry depicted of mortals' foolish attempts to challenge the gods as a thinly veiled warning. Arachne responded in a trance like state depicting the excesses of the gods and their lustful ways. Athena knew this couldn't go unpunished but before she could decide Arachne's fate, Arachne awoke from her trance like state, realised what she'd done and ran out of the house with a length of rope and hung herself from the nearest tree. Taking pity, Athena transformed her into a creature that would forever spend its days spinning and weaving, the first spider came into being and the word arachnid, named after her would apply to all spiders.

name: Rhodope
notes: Queen of Thrace, transformed into a mountain for daring to compare her and her husband's grandeur with that of Hera and Zeus. They were woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne to not challenge the gods.

name: Haemus
notes: King of Thrace, transformed into a mountain for daring to compare his and his wife's grandeur with that of Hera and Zeus. They were woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne to not challenge the gods.

name: Gerana
notes: Queen of the Pygmies. She proclaimed her beauty to be far greater than Hera's, the Queen of Heaven and was transformed into a crane-bird as punishment. She was woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne to not challenge the gods.

name: Antigone
notes: A Trojan citizen, not the daughter of Oedipus who had the same name. She angered the gods in a show of hubris and had her hair turned to snakes as a result. She was woven into a tapestry by Athena as a warning to Arachne that the gods should not be challenged.

name: Antigone
notes: Daughter of Oedipus and Jocasta, Oedipus' mother and wife. After Oedipus' demise her brothers, Eteocles and Polynices, agree to power share the throne of Thebes. But Eteocles reneged on the deal and Polynices raises an army (the so called Seven against Thebes) where both are killed in the ensuing battle. Polynices is denied proper burial as he was considered the agressor. Antigone, distraught at the idea of this attempts to cover the corpse but is caught and sentenced to death. Her sentence is commuted at the last minute but she hanged herself before she could get the news.

name: Oedipus
notes: His father, Laius, had received a prophecy that his son would kill him, so he had him imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron as a baby. He was rescued and taken to Corinth where he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope. They named him Oedipus which means 'swollen foot' after the scars on his once shackled ankles. During his life he heard rumours that he was adopted so he consulted with the Delphic oracle. Instead of being told who his real parents were, in typical oracular cryptic fashion he was told, "Oedipus will kill his father and mate with his mother". He decided to leave Corinth to avoid the possibility of the prophecy coming true. Whilst on the road he got into a fight with a man in a chariot who had hurled abuse at him to get out of the way, Oedipus killed him and his entourage during the ensuing fight. He ended up making his way toward Thebes, he answered one of the Sphinx's riddles on the way to reopen the road and lift the curse. He was welcomed into the city as a hero and welcomed by Queen Jocasta, unbeknownst to Oedipus, this was his real mother. She told him that her husband had been killed on the road by a gang of robbers, this was the very same fight that Oedipus had gotten into, part of the prophecy had come true. In time he fell in love with Jocasta. He became King and they married and had four children, thus completing the prophecy. Later in his reign he again sought the advice of the Delphic oracle about a vicious plague that had swept through the kingdom. The Pythia answered, "Thebes will be relieved when the murderer of King Laius is named and found." Oedipus sent for Laius' servant, Antimedes, who was the sole survivor of the fight that fateful day. As soon as Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus the whole horrendous truth came out. Oedipus discovered his true parents, his being abandoned by his mother and now wife, Jocasta, and the fact that the horrible prophecies had all come true. Jocasta ran away and hanged herself in the bedroom. Oedipus found her and thrust her gold brooch dress pins into his eyes in anguish.

name: Leda
notes: Zeus transformed into a swan to couple with her.

name: Tyndareus
notes: Heracles ousted his brother Hippoco√∂n and put Tyndareus, the rightful ruler of Sparta, on the throne, which would have devestating consequences. He held a wedding contest for his daughter, Helen, where suitors would bring gifts and try to win her hand. He bound all the suitors to an oath where they swore to honour his choice of suitor and to defend the marriage at all costs should it ever be violated. When Helen is later taken off to Troy, an army is sent to retrieve her sparking the Trojan war.

name: Dana√´
notes: Impregnated by Zeus who transformed into a shower of golden rain to reach her. He had to do this to get through the sealed chamber she was ensconced in due to her father, King Acrisius, being warned by the Delphic oracle that his grandson will kill him.

name: Acrisius
notes: King of Argos, he was warned by the Delphic oracle that he will not have a son, but that his grandson will kill him. In sheer terror he locked up his daughter in a sealed bronze chamber but Zeus, who had his eye on Dana√´, transformed into a shower of golden rain to get through the chamber and impregnate her.

name: Arne
notes: Arne of Thessaly. She was pursued by Poseidon who had transformed into a bull to chase her.

name: Enipeus
notes: Poseidon disguised himself as Enipeus so as to win over Tyro.

name: Melantho
notes: Poseidon transformed himself into a dolphin to win her affection.

name: Erigone
notes: Dionysus disguised himself as a cluster of grapes to win her love.

name: Alcatho√´
notes: Transformed into a bat when daring to prefer a contemplative life to one of Dionysian revelry.

name: Leucippe
notes: Transformed into a bat when daring to prefer a contemplative life to one of Dionysian revelry.

name: Arsippe
notes: Transformed into a bat when daring to prefer a contemplative life to one of Dionysian revelry.

name: Minyas
notes: nan

name: Nisus
notes: King of Megara in Attica, he had been granted invincibility in the form of a single lock of purple hair. His kingdom was attacked by King Minos of Crete. Nisus's daughter, Princess Scylla, fell in love with Minos and stole the lock of hair to give to Minos. Nisus became mortal at once and was later killed in a palace uprising.

name: Scylla
notes: Princess Scylla, daughter of King Nisus. She fell in love with King of Minos of Crete when he invaded their kingdom. So in love, she stole her father's lock of purple hair which had granted him invincibility to give to Minos. Her father, now mortal, was then killed in a palace uprising. Minos was far from pleased by her disloyalty and vowed to have nothing to do with her.  She couldn't give up and tried to swim after him, crying so much that she was turned into a gull. To the amusement of the gods her deceased father was turned into a sea-eagle and he has harried his daughter ever since.

name: Charybdis
notes: A sea-monster whose gigantic whirlpool swirled in the straits of Messina opposite the cliffs of the monster Scylla to form an almost impassable barrier to sailors between Sicily and the Italian mainland. Odysseus and his crew have to navigate between them on their way home to Ithaca.

name: Scylla
notes: A sea-monster who haunted the rocks of the Messina strait opposite the whirlpool of Charybdis to make an almost impassable barrier to sailors between Sicily and the Italian mainland. Odysseus and his crew have to navigate between them on their way home to Ithaca.

name: Callisto
notes: Raised as a nymph dedicated to the virgin huntress Artemis. Zeus so wanted her that he transformed his image into the exact one of Artemis herself and coupled with her. Artemis, disgusted with her impurity, discarded her from the group. She gave birth to a son, Arcas. In a double punishment Hera, never one to idly sit by and watch Zeus's dalliances, transformed Callisto into a bear. Some years later, Arcas almost killed Callisto when out hunting but was prevented from doing so by Zeus. He sent them both to the heavens as Ursa Major and Ursa Minor, the constellations Great Bear and Little Bear. Hera, still angry, deemed that they shall never share the same part of the sky, hence their permanently opposing positions.

name: Arcas
notes: Son of Zeus and Callisto, his mother was transformed into a bear by Hera angry at yet another one of Zeus's affairs. He would later almost commit an act of unknowing matricide whilst out hunting, but Zeus prevented it and sent him and his mother up to the heavens as the constellations Great Bear and Little Bear (Ursa Major and Minor). Hera, still angry, deemed that they shall never share the same part of the sky, hence their permanently opposing positions.

name: Pandion
notes: King of Athens.

name: Procne
notes: Wife of Tereus, King of Thrace who raped her sister Philomela and cut out her tongue to prevent her speaking of it. Philomela managed to show Procne what had happened in the form of a tapestry. Filled with a unquenching thirst for revenge, she murdered her own son, Ictys, the only person that Tereus loved. Ictys was served to Tereus as a stew which he lapped up. After he'd realised what had happened he gave chase but Procne was transformed into a swallow by the gods so she could make her escape.

name: Philomela
notes: She was raped by her sister's (Procne) husband, the evil King Tereus of Thrace. She then had her tongue ripped out so she couldn't tell her sister. She managed to depic the horrific event in a tapestry and showed her sister. They sought revenge by murdering the only thing Tereus loved, his son Ictys. They served Ictys in a stew which Tereus ate. When he found out he gave chase but Philomela was transformed into a nightingale by the gods so she could escape. Female nightingales to this day, remain mute.

name: Tereus
notes: King of Thrace, he was a despicable man who raped his wife's (Procne) sister, Philomela. Terrified that she would tell her sister, he tore out her tongue. Philomela managed to depict the horrific event in a tapestry and when her sister saw it they plotted revenge. They knew the only thing  Tereus would miss was his son, Ictys. Overwhelmed with revenge they murdered him and served him to Tereus at a banquet. Tereus found out, but not after eating most of his son and whilst chasing the sisters was transformed into a hoopoe bird, his yells of pain sounding like forlorn whoops.

name: Ictys
notes: Murdered by his mother, Procne, in revenge for his father's (Tereus) crime of raping her sister, Philomela. He was served to his father in a stew at a banquet.

name: Tros
notes: King Tros, ruler of a kingdom later named in his honour, Troy.

name: Ilos
notes: Found of Ilium, the region in which the famous city of Troy would be built. As such he is considered the first king of Troy.

name: Callirrho√´
notes: nan

name: Scamander
notes: Local river god of Troy.

name: Assaracus
notes: nan

name: Ganymede
notes: Son of Tros, the King of Troy, he was such a beautiful specimen of a man, handsome, polite, and excellent company that Zeus himself had to have him. He transformed into an eagle and plucked him up to Olympus to take him as his lover. Zeus compensated Tros with a set of divine horses which would come to be a integral part of the Trojan army and play a major role in the Trojan war.

name: Pandia
notes: nan

name: Ersa
notes: nan

name: Cephalus
notes: A fine, heroic youth, he caught the attention of Eos, the goddess of dawn, who abducted him. Cephalus was deeply unhappy, missing his wife Procris dreadfully. Eos decided to return him to his wife but was full of resentment, "how could a mere mortal be more irresistible than I?" She sowed seeds of doubt in Cephalus's mind as to his wife's faithfulness, convincing him to test her by appearing in disguise to see what she would do. When his wife finally submitted to this "stranger's" advances, Cephalus threw off his disguise and confronted her. Procris ran off to the woods in despair where she would be comforted by Artemis. Procris would eventually return to Cephalus with Artemis's blessing. In a tragic ending, Procris overheard him calling out to Zephyrus, the west wind. Mistaking his lascivious words for adultery, she shrieked in anguish and started Cephalus who reached for his hunting spear (a gift from Artemis to his wife that never missed its mark) and killed her.

name: Procris
notes: Wife of Cephalus who was abducted by Eos. Cephalus missed her so much that Eos agreed to return him to her. But, full of resentment, she tricked Cephalus into testing his wife's faithfulness. Cephalus was conned into wearing a disguise when he returned to her, and she eventually gave in to this "stranger's" overtures. Distraught when Cephalus removed his disguise she ran away to the woods. There she was comforted by Artemis who taught her the pleasures of shunning men, but eventually she admitted that she had to return to her beloved Cephalus. Artemis gave her blessing and bestowed upon her a gift of a remarkable hunting dog called Lailaps and a hunting spear that never missed its mark. Later in life she mistakingly overheard her husband's lascivious comments (he was talking to Zephyrus, the west wind, merely wanting to feel the wind on his skin), she mistook it as adultery and let out a shriek. Startled, Cephalus threw the hunting spear and killed her.

name: Praxithea
notes: nan

name: Lailaps
notes: Lailaps, a dog, was a gift from Artemis to Procris. A remarkable dog, it could catch anything that it pursued. It was loaned to Creon, King of Thebes, to hunt down a ferocious fox that was terrorising his kingdom. The fox, Alopex Teumesios (Cadmean Vixen) was divined never to be captured. What happens when the proverbial irresistible force meets immovable object? They were locked in an endless loop of chase and evade. Zeus, perplexed by this paradox, turned them to stone and brought them up to the heavens where they can be seen today as the constellations Canis Major and Canis Minor (Greater and Lesser Dogs).

name: Creon
notes: King of Thebes, ruling after King Laius was murdered by Oedipus, unbeknownst to him at the time, Laius was Oedipus' father. He abdicated the throne for Oedipus when he married Queen Jocasta, his mother. At the time of his reign, Thebes was being hounded by a viscious fox that couldn't be caught, the Cadmean Vixen. Creon begged Cephalus to let him use his hunting dog Lailaps to hunt the fox down.

name: Alopex Teumesios
notes: The Cadmean Vixen. This ruthless fox was the scourge of Thebes. The King, Creon, begged Cephalus for his marvellous hunting dog Lailaps to give chase to the fox. In the ensuing paradoxical chase, the fox, divined never to be caught, couldn't be captured by the dog, divined to catch everything it hunted. Round and round they went in an endless loop until Zeus, perplexed by this paradox, decided to turn them to stone, immortalising their endless chase for eternity. He brought them up to the heavens where they are to this day, the constellations Canis Major and Canis Minor, Greater and Lesser Dogs.

name: Endymion
notes: This young, handsome shepherd caught the eye of Selene, the moon goddess. The sight of him was so beautiful that she cried out to Zeus, Endymion's father, that he should never change and she wanted to see him like that every night. Zeus granted the wish and Endymion stayed just where he was. Each new moon, Selene would come down and make love to him. This story forms the subject of Keats's poem, Endymion.

name: Cleitus
notes: Another one of Eos's conquests, he died in a short time which caused Eos a lot of heartache. Unbeknownst to her, it was the curse of Aphrodite in full swing.

name: Laomedon
notes: Nephew of Zeus's beloved cupbearer Ganymede and King of Troy. He angered Heracles when he refused payment for one of his labours. Heracles sought revenge and killed him, sacking the city in the process.

name: Tithonus
notes: Lover of Eos, goddess of dawn. Eos, who unbeknownst to her had been cursed in love by Aphrodite for an affair with Ares, Aphrodite's lover, was forever unlucky in love. Determined for it not to happen again, she begged Zeus for Tithonus's immortality. He grinned, the curse of Aphrodite was at work, and granted the request. Later on, Eos, playfully stroking Tithonus's head, noticed a grey hair. Back she went to Zeus demanding an explanation. "You only asked for immortality, you said nothing about ageing", replied Zeus. Distraught, Eos had to watch her beloved Tithonus live on in extreme old age, unable to die. His wrinkled and shrivelled form was finally transformed by Eos, unable to bear it any more, into a grasshopper. Eos watched him skip away into the grass and somewhere Aphrodite let out a cruel laugh. A parable on being careful what you wish for,

name: Emathion
notes: Son of Eos, goddess of dawn, and Tithonus. Would go on to rule Arabia.

name: Memnon
notes: Son of Eos, goddess of dawn, and Tithonus. Would grow up to be one of the most fearless warriors in the ancient world. He brought an army to Troy to fight alongside the Trojans and killed Antilochus in a fierce battle.

name: Hyacinthus
notes: A beautiful Spartan prince, Hyacinthus was courted by two divinities, Zephyrus, the west wind, and Apollo. Hyacinthus rebuffed Zephyrus' charms much preferring Apollo. One day Apollo and Hyacinthus were participating in athletic events and Zephyrus, in a fit of jealous rage, blew Apollo's discus off course and struck Hyacinthus in the head, killing him. In tears of grief, Apollo mixed the blood that gushed from his beloved's head with his own tears. The resulting liquid seeped into the soil below and from it bloomed a magnificent flower, a flower that bears Hyacinth's name to this day.

name: Crocus
notes: Pined for the nymph Smilax without success. Out of pity was turned into the saffron flower that bears his name, whilst Smilax became a brambly vine that bears her name.

name: Smilax
notes: Pined for, without success, by Crocus. Out of pity Crocus was turned into the saffron flower that bears his name, whilst Smilax became a brambly vine that bears her name.

name: Theias
notes: King of Cyprus. Aphrodite, to which Cyprus was sacred, became angry with him for neglecting to make offerings to her. She cursed his daughter, Smyrna, with incestuous lust. One night when drunk, Smyrna's maid, Hippolyte, who was under a spell cast by Aphrodite, delivered Smyrna to her father's bed. Unknowingly he committed incest. The result of which was Adonis.

name: Cenchreis
notes: nan

name: Smyrna
notes: Cursed with lustful feelings for her father Theias, King of Cyprus, by Aphrodite who was unhappy with his neglect of her sacred birth place. She was eventually lured into her father's bed by Hippolyte, her maid, who was under a spell cast by Aphrodite. Her drunken father had no idea it was his daughter, but she, so distraught with what had happened begged the gods to put an end to this misery. She was transformed into a weeping myrrh tree. After ten months, the tree burst open and out came a baby boy, Adonis.

name: Hippolyte
notes: Led her friend Smyrna into bed with her father, Theias, under a spell cast by Aphrodite.

name: Adonis
notes: The result of incestuous love between Theias, King of Cyprus, and his daughter Smyrna. He attracted the attention of Aphrodite, who had caused his birth in the first place by cursing his mother with incestuous thoughts due to Theias's neglect of her sacred birth place of Cyprus. He was killed by a wild boar, some say this was a jealous Ares in disguise. A distraught Aphrodite vowed from then on that love would be forever tinged with tragedy as she prophesised whilst holding a dying Adonis in her arms, "Sorrow on love hereafter shall attend..., It shall be cause of war and dire events, And set dissension 'twixt the son and sire..., They that love best their loves shall not enjoy."

name: Cassandra
notes: A Trojan prophetess (select mortals were also blessed with the gift of prophecy). Although gifted with entirely accurate prophecies, they were tempered by the fact that they would always be entirely unbelieved by the recipient. This was to become fateful to the Trojans when she tried to warn them about the Greek forces hiding in the wooden horse, but nobody would believe her. At the fall of Troy she was raped by Ajax the Lesser in a temple dedicated to Athena. She was eventually taken by King Agamemnon as a concubine. Cassandra was murdered beside Agamemnon by his treacherous wife Clytemnestra and her lover Aegisthus.

name: Tiresias
notes: Born male, he was turned into a female by Hera as a punishment for striking two mating snakes with a stick. She was then brought up to Olympus to arbitrate a wager between Zeus and Hera as to who enjoyed sex the most, males or females. Having experience of both she was best placed to answer this question. She answered that it was females who enjoyed sex more. This enraged Hera who wanted to prove it was men who enjoyed it more, probably due to Zeus's unconquerable libido. For this heinous crime Hera struck Tiresias blind. Having sympathy, Zeus awarded him the gift of second sight, prophecy. His prophecies help Odysseus on his return home to Ithaca after the Trojan war.

name: Liriope
notes: nan

name: Cephissus
notes: nan

name: Narcissus
notes: Blessed with stunning beauty, his mother, the nymph Liriope, was concerned. Stunning beauty made him a target of the gods so she consulted with the prophet Tiresias who told them that "as long as Narcissus doesn't recognise himself, he will live a long and happy life". He grew to hate the concept of love, believing it to render its subjects stupid and helpless. One day whilst near a lake he was approached by Echo, a nymph cursed by Hera to be only able to repeat words spoken to her. Annoyed at her advances he chased her away. He looked into the lake and noticed his reflection. He fell deeply in love but every time he approached the reflection to kiss it, it would disappear into a thousand ripples. This curse of longing for one's self and how one appears in other's eyes gives us the modern day mental condition, narcissism.

name: Echo
notes: Echo, blessed with the gift of talking and a beatiful, mellifluous voice, lied to Hera to protect Zeus who was having an affair with a nymph nearby. When Hera found out she cursed Echo's gift of talking. From then on she could only repeat what people said to her. One day she stumbled upon Narcissus and fell instantly in love with him. Unable to do anything but repeat his words, she angered him and was chased away. Aphrodite took pity on her and relieved her of her human form that was bound in pain of unrequited love, which just left her voice behind which can still be heard in empty rooms and caves to this day.

name: Ameinias
notes: Fell in love with Narcissus, but the love was sadly not reciprocated. He hung himself from a tree outside Narcissus's house.

name: Pyramus
notes: Fell in love with Thisbe, who was daughter of his family's hated rivals in Babylon. They maintained a secret liason until one day they decided to elope together away from their warring families. At the rendezvous point, Thisbe encountered a lion and ran away.
