When Pyramus arrived he saw Thisbe's veil on the ground, lion paw prints, and blood from the lion's meal earlier that day. Fearing that his beloved Thisbe had been eaten, he fell on his own sword in despair. When Thisbe returned she puts the tragic pieces of the puzzle before her back together. Condenming the gods for not allowing them to be together, she takes Pyramus's sword and kills herself. The grief of both families ending up uniting them in peace.

name: Thisbe
notes: Fell in love with Pyramus, who was son of her family's hated rivals in Babylon. They maintained a secret liason until one day they decided to elope together away from their warring families. At the rendezvous point, Thisbe encountered a lion and ran away. When Pyramus arrived he saw Thisbe's veil on the ground, lion paw prints, and blood from the lion's meal earlier that day. Fearing that his beloved Thisbe had been eaten, he fell on his own sword in despair. When Thisbe returned she puts the tragic pieces of the puzzle before her back together. Condenming the gods for not allowing them to be together, she takes Pyramus's sword and kills herself. The grief of both families ending up uniting them in peace.

name: Ninus
notes: Assyrian King and founder of the great city of Nineveh.

name: Semiramis
notes: nan

name: Nereus
notes: The Old Man of the Sea and God of the sea's fishes.

name: Galatea
notes: Daughter of the Oceanid Doris and sea god Nereus, she attracted the unwanted attention of a cyclopes, Polyphemus. Rebuffing him he killed her lover Acis in retaliation. The grieving Galatea was able to turn Acis into an immortal river spirit so as not to lose him.

name: Polyphemus
notes: Not one of the original cyclopes, he was the ugly offspring of Poseidon and Thoosa. He fell in love with Galatea but this was not reciprocated. He killed Galatea's lover, Acis, in retribution. He captures Odysseus and his men on their return to Ithaca after they venture into his cave. Odysseus uses his cunning to overcome him and he blinds his one eye with a wooden stake. This incurs the wrath of Poseidon who makes it his personal mission to make Odysseus' journey home as difficult as possible.

name: Thoosa
notes: nan

name: Acis
notes: Lover of Galatea, he was killed by her admirer, the cyclopes Polyphemus as revenge for his rebuffed advances. Galatea transformed him into an immortal river spirit to be with him for eternity.

name: Symaethis
notes: nan

name: Pandion
notes: Pandion of Phaestos in Crete.

name: Lampros
notes: nan

name: Galatea
notes: nan

name: Leucippos
notes: Born a girl, her father only wanted boys, and told her mother, Galatea, that if she gave birth to a girl she should kill it. Galatea hid the truth from Lampros until she reached the age when it would start to show. She took Leucippos to the temple of Leto, where she prayed that her daughter might change sex. Leto answered and Leucippos was transformed into a man.

name: Oenomaus
notes: King of Pisa in the Peloponnese. It was prophecised that he would be killed by a son-in-law. Being the greatest charioteer in the land, he challenged any would be suitor of his daughter, Hippodamia, to a race, if they lost, they paid with their life.

name: Leucippos
notes: Another Leucippos of sex changing fame, this one had the temerity to fall in love with the naiad Daphne, who was courted by Apollo. Leucippos disguised himself as a girl to gain entry to the retinue of nymphs. The nymphs discovered his secret and speared him to death.

name: Daphne
notes: Pursued by Leucippos, who tried to slip into her group of nymphs disguised as a girl to get near her, was discovered and speared to death. Apollo had his eye on her during this time. He materialised in front of Daphne who ran away. He gave chase but Daphne sent up a prayer to her mother Gaia and her father, the river god Ladon, to help. They transformed her into a laurel tree. Apollo was chastened, and the laurel would become sacred to him. Victors at the Pythian Games would be awarded a laurel wreath, and the winner of a great prize is still called a laureate to this day.

name: Pygmalion
notes: Pygmalion of Cyprus became so disgusted with the lack of modesty and chastity on the island that he vowed never to fall under its spell. This angered Aphrodite. One day whilst sculpting what he thought was a male body, he took a step back and noticed that he had in fact carved the most beautiful woman he had ever seen. He named her Galatea. Aphrodite then cursed him to fall in love with the statue. She eventually agreed to Pygmalion's prayers that Galatea should be transformed into an actual human. They lived happily ever after.

name: Galatea
notes: Carved from marble by Pygmalion who fell deeply in love with her. He begged Aphrodite to turn her into human form. She duly obliged and they lived happily ever after.

name: Paphos
notes: Named after the town of his birth in Cyprus.

name: Ladon
notes: Hundred-headed draconian guardian of the Golden Apples of Hesperides. Was killed by Heracles when he was tasked with retrieving the Apples as one of his labours.

name: Daphnis
notes: Lover of both Hermes and Pan, Pan taught him to play the pipes. He became so proficient that he was credited with being the founder of pastoral poetry.

name: Leander
notes: Lover of Hero, they lived on each side of the Dardanelles, or Hellespont as it was called back then. Hero would light a lamp in her window which would guide Leander to her as he swam across the strait. One day the winds blew out the lamp, Leander couldn't find his way and drowned. Hero awoke to see him dead on the rocks below and she dashed herself on the same rocks in despair.

name: Hero
notes: Lover of Leander, they lived on each side of the Dardanelles, or Hellespont as it was called back then. Hero would light a lamp in her window which would guide Leander to her as he swam across the strait. One day the winds blew out the lamp, Leander couldn't find his way and drowned. Hero awoke to see him dead on the rocks below and she dashed herself on the same rocks in despair.

name: Boreas
notes: nan

name: Notus
notes: nan

name: Oncaea
notes: nan

name: Arion
notes: Son of Poseidon and the nymph Oncaea, he devoted his life to music becoming the greatest musician in the land. His patron, Periander, King of Corinth, sent him to Italy for a music competition which he won easily. He was sailing back with his prize money when the crew of the ship stole his treasure and were just about to kill him when he begged them to play one last song. This final song was an offering to his father Poseidon. He then jumped overboard and was rescued from drowning by a dolphin. Returning to Corinth, Arion ordered that the dolphin be taken care of. Sadly it was left out in the sun too long and died. Periander ordered a high tower to be built to commemorate the dolphin. One day later, the ship that Arion had escaped from was blown into Corinth by a storm. Periander asked them where the treasure was. The crew lied saying that it was lost overboard along with their dear friend Arion. As soon as they told this lie Arion emerged from the dolphin's tower and Periander ordered them all to be executed. After his death Apollo, to whom dolphins were sacred, set Arion and his rescue dolphin amongst the stars between Sagittarius and Aquarius, the Dolphin constellation which aided navigators for years later.

name: Periander
notes: King of Corinth, he was also patron of the greatest musician in the land, Arion.

name: Philemon
notes: He and his wife Baucis passed Hermes' and Zeus' test of hospitality. The only set of people in their village to do so. Zeus ordered them to the top of the hill overlooking the town where he transformed them into oak and linden trees to spend the rest of eternity together. The rest of the town perished in a great flood.

name: Baucis
notes: He and his wife Baucis passed Hermes' and Zeus' test of hospitality. The only set of people in their village to do so. Zeus ordered them to the top of the hill overlooking the town where he transformed them into oak and linden trees to spend the rest of eternity together. The rest of the town perished in a great flood.

name: Gordias
notes: A poor man from Macedonia, Gordias luck turned when the nearby city of Phrygia, whose king had recently deceased, were trying to appoint a successor. An oracle told them that the next person to enter the city in a cart should be crowned King. This was Gordias. He rebuilt the city and named it Gordium in his honour. The cart became a holy relic. It was secured by the most intricate knot known to man, so determined was Gordias that it not be stolen. This is the famous Gordian Knot that lay undone for a thousand years until a young Macedonian entered the city and sliced the knot open with his sword. The young man's name, Alexander, who would earn the sobriquet "The Great" for his actions.

name: Midas
notes: Son of Gordias, he took over his father's throne as King of Phrygia upon his death. One day he encountered Silenus, Dionysus's sidekick, in a drunken revelry. He showed him much hospitality which was rewarded by Dionysus with any wish he wanted. Having a rush of blood to the head perhaps, and because his kingdom was struggling for money, he wished for anything that he touched be turned to gold. His wish was granted but he quickly realised this was indeed, a curse. Even his wife and daughter were transformed, he couldn't touch anything. Pleading with Dionysus, who told him he was lucky that Silenus was so fond of him, made it so that anything he washed in the nearby river would be transformed back again. A relieved Midas quickly restored his wife and daughter back to human form. He then devoted his life to a more bucolic existence becoming a follower of Pan, the god of nature. One day when Pan and Apollo were playing music, Midas had the temerity to say that Pan's playing was better than Apollo's. Luckily he caught Apollo in a good mood and his only punishment was to have his ear's transformed into those of an ass, becuase only the ears of an ass could not appreciate such music. From then on he wore a turban to keep his ears a secret, only his barber knew the truth. His barber, unable to keep it a secret any longer, buried the words, "Midas has the ears of an ass" in the ground. This would grow into a flower which released the words into the wild. When Midas heard them and was scorned by his subjects he drank poison and killed himself.

name: Enceladus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Enceladus was the most powerful of all the giants. He was killed by Athena and buried under Mount Etna where he grumbles to this day (Enceladus means 'the noisy one').

name: Polybotes
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. He was crushed under a section of the island of Kos that Poseidon broke off and thrust on top of him.

name: Damysus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the conquerer and famous for the speed of his feet, he was killed early in the war but was exhumed later by Chiron, who extracted his feet and implanted the speed into the heels of Achilles.

name: Mimas
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the imitator, he was killed by Hephaestus who poured a vat of molten iron all over him.

name: Clytius
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the renowned, was consumed in the flames of Hecate's torches.

name: Syceus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Was going to be killed by Zeus when Gaia intervened and transformed him into a fig tree.

name: Hippolytus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the stampeder of horses, he was killed by Hermes who cheated by wearing his invisibility cloak.

name: Typhoeus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the smoulderer, he was killed by Dionysus with his sacred thyrsus.

name: Aristaeus
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the best, he was spared from the war by Gaia who transformed him into a dung beetle.

name: Thoon
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the swift.

name: Phoitios
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the reckless.

name: Molios
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy.

name: Emphytos
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the rooted one.

name: Porphyrion
notes: One of the giants who fought the Olympians during the Gigantomachy. Known as the purple one, he was killed by Zeus when he tried to rape Hera.

name: Astraios
notes: nan

name: Ismenian Dragon
notes: A giant serpent that guarded the sacred spring of Ares near Thebes. Cadmus killed it and to placate Ares, on instructions from Athena, sowed the dragon's teeth, which produced a crop of fully-grown, armed warriors called the Spartoi who would go on to become the ancestral lords of Thebes. Ares would have his revenge later, transforming Cadmus and his wife into serpents.

name: Nike
notes: Winged goddess of victory - victory in war and peaceful competition. Stood at Zeus' throne with her three siblings Kratos, Bia and Zelos after they came to Zeus' aide in the Titan war.

name: Kratos
notes: Along with his three siblings Nike, Bia and Zelos, were the winged enforcers of Zeus who stood in attendance of the heavenly throne.

name: Bia
notes: Along with his three siblings Nike, Bia and Zelos, were the winged enforcers of Zeus who stood in attendance of the heavenly throne.

name: Zelos
notes: Along with his three siblings Nike, Bia and Zelos, were the winged enforcers of Zeus who stood in attendance of the heavenly throne.

name: Perseus
notes: Son of Dana√´ and Zeus, and grandson of King Acrisius of Argos who was warned by the Delphic oracle that his grandson would kill him. Acrisius locked Dana√´ and the infant Perseus in a wooden chest and hurled into the sea to prevent the proclomation coming true. Was tricked by Polydectes into bringing him the head of Medusa so he could move in on his mother, Dana√´. He would then go on a quest and become the prototypical Greek hero. With weapons provided by Athena and Hermes he defeated Medusa. He would go on to rescue Andromeda, and they would become lovers. He then took revenge on Polydectes by turning him to stone with Medusa's head. Later, whilst travelling mainland Greece with Andromeda, he took part in an athletics event. He threw the discus so far it struck someone in the crowd, when he went to comfort him he caught the man's dying breath, "I defeated the Oracle, it said I would be killed by my grandson". But the man was indeed Perseus' grandfather, the same man who had bundled Danae and Perseus into the sea in a wooden chest to prevent the prophecy becoming true. After appeasing the Gods for this accidental killing, Perseus and Andromeda would live happily ever after, they were brought up to the heavens as constellations.

name: Dictys
notes: Rescued Dana√´ and Perseus from their wooden chest.

name: Polydectes
notes: King of Seriphos and brother of Dictys who adopted Perseus. Tricked Perseus into bringing him the head of Medusa just so he could move in on his mother, Dana√´. When Dana√´ rebuffed his advances he had her along with Dictys executed, but Perseus returned just in time to save them, deploying his new favourite weapon of Medusa's head to turn him into stone.

name: Hippodamia
notes: nan

name: Pyrrho
notes: Friend of Perseus.

name: Pemphredo
notes: One of the Graeae, or Grey Ones, sisters of the Gorgons who had one eye and one tooth between three of them, her name means 'she who guides the way'.

name: Enyo
notes: One of the Graeae, or Grey Ones, sisters of the Gorgons who had one eye and one tooth between three of them, her name means 'warlike'.

name: Dino
notes: One of the Graeae, or Grey Ones, sisters of the Gorgons who had one eye and one tooth between three of them, her name means 'terrible'.

name: Chrysaor
notes: Child of Poseidon and Medusa, was held in Medusa's womb when she was punished by Athena until Perseus beheaded her and Chrysaor could emerge bearing a weapon of shining gold. His name means 'golden sword'.

name: Pegasus
notes: Child of Poseidon and Medusa, was held in Medusa's womb when she was punished by Athena until Perseus beheaded her and Pegasus emerged as a shimmering white, winged horse. He first went to Mount Helicon where he struck his hoof on the ground and water bubbled up to become the famous Hippocrene, horse fountain. Ended up at Corinth where he was tamed by Bellerophon. He was always at Bellerophons' side during his many heroic feats until the day hubris got the better of Bellerophon and he flew up to Olympus believing he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Instead Zeus punished his arrogance by striking him down onto the rocks below, and keeping Pegasus on Olympus to carry his thunderbolts.

name: Andromeda
notes: Chained to a rock by Poseidon because her mother, Cassiopeia had incurred his wrath by claiming that she was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Was saved by Perseus and they fell in love. Would be taken up to the heavens as a constellation as a reward for living a good life by Zeus.

name: Cepheus
notes: King of Ethiopia, father of Andromeda.

name: Cassiopeia
notes: Queen of Ethiopia, mother of Andromeda. She angered the sea god Poseidon by claiming Andromeda was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world.

name: Cetus
notes: A sea dragon that was sent by Poseidon to ravage the shoreline of the kingdom of Cepheus and Cassiopeia for their blasphemous claims that their daughter Andromeda was more beautiful than all of the Nereids and Oceanids in the world. Perseus would kill the dragon and save Andromeda's life.

name: Phineus
notes: Was promised Andromeda as a wife so as to unite the kingdoms of the Nile. He was not impressed when she fell in love with Perseus instead, he confronted Perseus with his army and ordered him to leave, but Perseus showed them the head of Medusa and they all turned to stone.

name: Sthenelus
notes: Member of the Greek forces during the Trojan war.

name: Nicippe
notes: Zeus had chosen Alcmene instead of Nicippe to bear his child to fulfill Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. Just before Alcmene was to give birth he exhorted that "the next child born of the house of Perseus will rule all Argolis". But unbeknownst to him, Hera had crafted a plan to get Nicippe to give birth first as revenge on Zeus' affair, Eurystheus was the result.

name: Amphitryon
notes: nan

name: Alcmene
notes: Impregnated by Zeus as he wanted to guard against Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. He decided that who would be better than a descendant of Perseus and a son of his own? He disguised himself as Electryon, Alcmene's husband. Hera, angered at yet another dalliance, ordered her daughter Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth to prevent the offspring being born. Alcemene got help from Galanthis and Historis who tricked Eileithyia into thinking the baby had been born. She was then able to give birth to twins, Alcides (later to become Heracles) and Iphicles, Alcides by Zeus, and Iphicles by Electryon.

name: Electryon
notes: nan

name: Eileithyia
notes: Daughter of Hera and goddess of childbirth. Also known as Ilithyia or Natio to the Romans.

name: Eurystheus
notes: Zeus had chosen Alcmene instead of Nicippe to bear his child to fulfill Hera's prophecy that someone from the line of Perseus would save the Olympians. Just before Alcmene was to give birth he exhorted that "the next child born of the house of Perseus will rule all Argolis". But unbeknownst to him, Hera had crafted a plan to get Nicippe to give birth first as revenge on Zeus' affair, Eurystheus was the result. He would take the throne as Zeus had inadvertenly promised, and in Hera's cruel twist of fate Heracles would be ordered to serve Eurystheus after he mistakenly killed his family. Eurystheus would send Heracles on his labours to atone for his sins.

name: Galanthis
notes: Friend of Alcmene, came to her aid when Hera had cursed her not to give birth as it was Zeus' child. Tricked Eileithyia into releasing her lock on Alcmene's legs enabling her to finally give birth. Hera turned her into a weasel as punishment.

name: Historis
notes: Friend of Alcmene, came to her aid when Hera had cursed her not to give birth as it was Zeus' child. Tricked Eileithyia into releasing her lock on Alcmene's legs enabling her to finally give birth.

name: Iphicles
notes: Step-brother of Heracles.

name: Eurytus
notes: King of Oechalia, the most famed bowman in Greece, he taught Heracles his archery skills. Was a member of the Greek forces during the Trojan war.

name: Linus
notes: Brother of Orpheus, he was also a fine musician and taught Heracles how to play the lyre. The arts were not Heracle's strength however and when Linus tried to discipline him, Heracles saw the red mist and threw Linus against the far side of the room killing him instantly.

name: Eumolpus
notes: Son of Autolycus, rascally son of Hermes, he took up Heracle's music tuition after Heracles killed his previous teacher, Linus, in a fit of rage.

name: Kastor
notes: Twin of Polydeuces, he trained Heracles in the use of weaponry. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

name: Polydeuces
notes: Twin of Castor. He was one of Jason's Argonauts.

name: Thespis
notes: King of Thespiae. Heracles killed the dreaded Mount Cithaeron lion that was terrorising Thespis' kingdom. He rewarded him with the hand of his daughter, Megara.

name: Erginos
notes: King of Orchomenos, he attacked Thebes but was defeated by Heracles. The people of Thebes would go on to venerate Heracles, the greatest Theban since their founder Cadmus.

name: Megara
notes: Wife of Heracles, they had a son and daughter together. One fateful day when Heracles returned home he was confronted by a demon and two dragons at his front door, Heracles being Heracles he quickly dispatched them but when he looked at the corpses he saw it was in fact his wife and children. This was the work of Hera, in one of her cruelest interventions she had stripped Heracles of everything that mattered to him, his family and his standing in the community.

name: Chimera
notes: A two-headed monster with a lion's body and head, a goat's head rising from its back, the udders of a goat, and a serpent's tail. Killed by the hero Bellerophon.

name: Nemean Lion
notes: A fierce lion with an impenetrable hide. Heracles was ordered to kill it as one of his labours. He managed to wrestle it into submission after a fierce fight and killed it. He would wear its hide over his shoulders and a necklace of its claws around his neck.

name: Iolaus
notes: Son of Iphicles and nephew of Heracles, he helped Heracles defeat the Lernaean Hydra.

name: Ceryneian Hind
notes: A golden-horned, brass-footed doe, sacred to Artemis. Eurystheus ordered Heracles to bring her to him as one of his labours, knowing full well that she wasn't a threat to anyone but it would result in his certain death at the hands of Artemis. He managed to capture her but was confronted by Artemis who was just about to kill him when Apollo emerged and told her the entire story. It amused Artemis to aid an enemy of Hera (Hera wasn't fond of any child of Zeus that wasn't hers, and the feelings were mutual) so she ordered him to release the hind as soon as he showed her to Eurystheus.

name: Erymanthian Boar
notes: A giant boar that ravaged the area around Mount Erymanthus in Arcadia. Heracles was ordered to kill it as one of his labours. Heracles captured the boar and took it back alive. A terrified Eurystheus leapt into a giant stone jar to hide from it which would become an amusing and favourite scene for Greek pot painters.

name: Pholus
notes: Heracles sought Pholus' advice on where to find the Erymanthian Boar. Whilst staying with him he mistakenly drank some centaur wine and an argument broke out. The row became a fight and Heracles set loose a volley of arrows, whose tips were poisoned with the venemous blood of Hydra. Pholus was killed in the fight.

name: Nessus
notes: A centaur who survived the fight with Heracles (see Pholus for the details). Years later he would meet Heracles and his wife Deianira trying to cross the River Euinos. Heracles didn't recognise him, but he certainly recognised Heracles. Whilst transporting Deianira across the river he tried to molest her. Heracles fired his Hydra poisoned arrows at him, as he lay dying he tricked Deianira into taking his blood stained shirt telling her that it was charmed and that it will ignite a failing marriage, all she has to do is make him wear it. A few years later Deianira did indeed give Heracles the shirt, the Hydra poison worked its way through his mighty body causing him the most agonising death.

name: Augeas
notes: King of Elis, he possessed a sacred herd of three thousand cattle. Heracles was ordered to clean out the stables, which hadn't been cleaned in over thirty years, in a single day. He managed to do this by diverting two local rivers, the Peneus and the Alpheus to sluice out the stables. The manure rich torrents swept onto the plains of Elis and fertilised the lands for miles around, pleasing the entire population. Heracles, who had been promised a reward by Augeas, returned to claim his prize of three-hundred of the cattle. Augeas reneged on the deal and Heracles swore revenge. He returned in later years to kill Augeas and placed his exiled son, Phyleus, who supported Heracles in the original dispute on the throne. Heracles established athletic competitions here, every four years, which he named in honour of his father's home, the Olympic games. Before his death he was also one of Jason's Argonauts.

name: Phyleus
notes: Son of Augeas, he stuck up for Heracles when Augeas reneged on the deal to clean out the Augean stables for three-hundred of his cattle. He was exiled to Dulichium, an island in the Ionian Sea as punishment. Later when Heracles took revenge on Augeas, he was placed on the throne in his place.

name: Stymphalian Birds
notes: Fearsome man-eating birds the size of cranes with beaks of iron, talons of brass and toxic droppings. Sacred to Ares, the god of war. Heracles was ordered to rid them from Lake Stymphalia. He couldn't get near to them as the ground near them was swampland. Athena came to his aid by providing him a great bronze rattle, manufactured by Hephaestus, to flush the birds out from the swamp where he was then able to  shoot them down and scare the rest away.

name: Cretan Bull
notes: Sent from the sea by Posedion in answer to the prayers of Minos, the King of Crete who wanted a sign that his reign was blessed. Heracles was sent to subdue it as one of his labours. When Heracles released the bull it fled to Marathon, where it became known as the Marathonian Bull and terrorised the inhabitants there until Theseus came along and subdued the bull. He then sacrificed it to Apollo.

name: Minos II
notes: King of Crete. He demanded a yearly tribute from Athens for the death of his son, Androgeus, who died trying to subdue the Marathonian Bull on the King of Athens' orders (King Aegeus). Theseus, Aegeus' son, went to Crete as part of the tribute and killed Asterion the minotaur, the one for whom the tribute was for. Minos blamed Daedalus, the inventor of the labyrinth which imprisoned Asterion. Daedalus escaped but Minos eventually tracked him down to Sicily where he demanded King Cocalus hand him over. Cocalus' daughters, very fond of Daedalus, scalded him to death in the bath before he had chance to take him.

name: Pasiphae
notes: Queen of Crete, she mated with the Cretan Bull and bore the minotaur Asterion.

name: Asterion
notes: Son of the Cretan Bull and Pasiphae, Queen of Crete. This half man, half bull, known as a Minotaur, lived in the labyrinth designed by King Minos of Crete's architect, Daedalus.

name: Daedalus
notes: The most gifted architect, inventor, designer in all of ancient Greece. Born in Athens but was expelled when he threw his nephew and apprentice Perdix off the Acropolis in a jealous rage as Perdix had become even more gifted than Daedalus himself. He went to Crete where he would work for King Minos.  He designed the labyrinth that imprisoned the minotaur Asterion for King Minos of Crete. When Theseus killed Asterion Minos blamed Daedalus. Only the inventor of the labyrinth could have helped him on his way through. He imprisoned Daedalus and his son, Icarus, at the top of the palace tower. Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus flew too high and his wings melted. He crashed into the sea and died. Daedalus eventually ended up working for King Cocalus in Sicily. One day he was presented with a puzzle, passing a thread through a shell's complex helical chambers. Daedalus did this with ease and showed the man how he did it. The man was pleased, only Daedalus the inventor could have solved this puzzle. The man was Minos. He had finally tracked Daedalus down and wanted revenge. Cocalus reluctantly agreed to hand him over the next day but whilst Minos was bathing in the palace, Cocalus' daughters, so very fond of Daedalus, heated the water to boiling point and scalded Minos to death.

name: Diomedes
notes: King of Thrace. Heracles was sent to get his four mares as one of his labours. The horses killed Heracles' lover, Abderus during the quest. Heracles unleashed the full force of his wrath on Diomedes as a result and he fed him to his own horses. The unpleasant taste of their former master caused the mares to lose the taste for human flesh and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

name: Alcestis
notes: Queen of Pherae alongside King Admetus. She agreed to die for Admetus who was promised immortality by Apollo and the Moirai if he could find someone to take his place. Admetus was so distraught that Heracles rescued her from Thanatos as he was taking her soul to the underworld.

name: Pelias
notes: He had nine daughters, the most beautiful, Alcestis, was promised only to the man who was able to harness a boar and a lion to a chariot. Admetus, with help from his friend and lover Apollo, was the only one who managed this feat, and the two were wed. Believed he was the rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos when King Cretheus died (Cretheus' wife, Tyro, was his mother by the sea god Poseidon). He besieged Iolcos alongside his brother Neleus which caused the rightful heir, Aeson, to smuggle out his firstborn child, Jason, of Golden Fleece fame. He slaughtered everyone connected to Cretheus and imprisoned Aeson and his wife Alcimede. He also killed Sidero, Cretheus' second wife, who mistreated his mother, but he mistakenly did this in a temple dedicated to Hera, the Queen of Heaven. She swore revenge, of all the gods she was the most dangerous an enemy, just ask Heracles. Pelias, troubled by this, seeks advice from an oracle who informs him that "One of your own blood will end your life, beware the man who comes from the country wearing but one sandal". The prophecy came true one fateful day when Jason wandered into the city. He had lost a sandal on the journey helping an old woman (Hera in disguise) across a river. Pelias, terrified, tricked agreed to let him have the throne but told him that the land was cursed and the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece.

name: Pheres
notes: nan

name: Podargos
notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'flashing-footed'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. Heracles was commanded to retrieve the horses as one of his labours. When his friend and lover, Abderus, was killed during the quest, he fed Diomedes to the horses in revenge. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

name: Xanthippe
notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'yellow horse'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. Heracles was commanded to retrieve the horses as one of his labours. When his friend and lover, Abderus, was killed during the quest, he fed Diomedes to the horses in revenge. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

name: Lampon
notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'shining one'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. Heracles was commanded to retrieve the horses as one of his labours. When his friend and lover, Abderus, was killed during the quest, he fed Diomedes to the horses in revenge. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

name: Dinos
notes: One of Diomede's mares, the 'terrible'. Diomedes fed them human flesh and they became quite mad and dangerous. Heracles was commanded to retrieve the horses as one of his labours. When his friend and lover, Abderus, was killed during the quest, he fed Diomedes to the horses in revenge. The horses lost their appetite for human flesh as a result and Heracles was able to ride them back to Eurystheus.

name: Abderus
notes: Friend and lover of Heracles, he aided him in one of his labours to retrieve the four mares of Diomedes but was killed by the horses during the quest. Heracles buried his remains and founded a city around the tomb, which he called Abdera in his honour.

name: Admete
notes: Daughter of Eurystheus, who commanded Heracles on his labours to atone for the killing of his family. She was given a labour of Heracles by her father as a present. She ordered Heracles to bring her the girdle of Hippolyta, the Queen of the Amazons, a fierce band of strong, independent women.

name: Hippolyta
notes: Queen of the Amazons, a fierce band of strong, independent female warriors, the daughters of Ares, the god of war. They were the first warriors to ride on horseback and when they conquered a territory they would choose the best men for mating and kill them, raising only girls to join their group. Heracles was ordered to steal her jewelled girdle as one of his labours. When Heracles reached the Amazons news of his labours had spread far and wide and he was welcomed as a hero and equal. Hippolyta gifted her girdle to Heracles as a gesture of goodwill. Hera, incensed at the ease of how he achieved this labour, snuck amongst the Amazons and tricked them into attacking Heracles. Heracles killed Hippolyta thinking it was a trap sprung by her.

name: Hesione
notes: Daughter of Laomedon, King of Troy. He had to appease Apollo and Poseidon, who had helped build Troy, because he had refused them the necessary sacrifices. The penance was that he had to chain his daughter, Hesione, to a rock for Poseidon's sea monster to feast upon. Heracles promised to free her in return for the horses that Zeus had gifted to Tros (the founder of Troy) in return for his son Ganymede. Heracles kep his side of the bargain but Laomedon reneged, he vowed one day to take revenge.

name: Geryon
notes: A three-headed monster who fiercely protected an enormous herd of red cattle in Erytheia. Killed by Heracles when he was ordered to retrieve the cattle as one of his labours.

name: Callirrho√´
notes: The 'sweet-flowing' daughter of the sea Titans Oceanus and Tethys.

name: Eurytion
notes: A giant, and son of Ares, the god of war. He helped Geryon guard his prized cattle. Killed by Heracles when he was tasked with retrieving the cattle as one of his labours.

name: Orthrus
notes: A ferocious two-headed dog, brother of Cerberus, the hound of hell. He guarded Geryon's cattle. Killed by Heracles when he was tasked with retrieving the cattle as one of his labours.

name: Antaeus
notes: A half-giant, he would challenge passers by to wrestling matches, the loser of which must die. Heracles challenged him to match but struggled to defeat him as every time Antaeus hit the ground, he would get stronger. Heracles realised that as a child of Gaia, mother earth, he had to keep him off the ground to defeat him. He got him in a bear hug off the ground and managed to defeat him.

name: Cercyon
notes: A giant of a man, he challenged travellers to wrestling matches. Theseus encountered him on his heroic travels where he used wit and skill to Cercyon's brute strength. Cercyon tired and Theseus managed to best him by tripping him over some cliffs. To the Greeks this would be the birth of modern wrestling.

name: Busiris
notes: Son of Aegyptus in Egypt, the Greeks had a distaste for the human sacrifices performed by the priests of Osiris, from whom Busiris got his name. Heracles offered himself to as the next sacrifice but just before he was to be killed, he burst open from his chains and killed Busiris. He renamed the town of Busiris, Thebes, in honour of the city of his birth. Hence the need to distinguish between Thebes in Greece, and Thebes in Egypt, which is contained within the cities of Luxor and Karnak.

name: Pirithous
notes: King of the Lapiths and one of Jason's Argonauts. He heard of the exploits of Theseus and wanted to test them out. He raided his cattle and Theseus tracked him down, but instead of fighting it out they quickly realised they very much liked each other and so began one of the great friendships in Greek mythology. They had the crazy idea of kidnapping Persephone, Queen of the Underworld to be his wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks glued to the seats. It wasn't until Heracles descended into the underworld during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus, that they managed to be freed.

name: Meleager
notes: One of Jason's Argonauts. He was son of either Oeneus, King of Calydon, or Ares, the god of war. His mother, Althaea, fell into a deep sleep after giving birth where she dreamed that the Moirai, or Fates, had decided that his life would be noble, potentially being the son of Ares and all, but his life would only last as long as the central log in the fireplace by which his mother slept remained unburned. "Meleager's life will end in a flash, when his log of fate is turned to ash" they chanted. He was a member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar that terrorised his father's kingdom. He fell instantly in love with Atalanta who joined the hunt. This wasn't reciprocated however because as a subject of the god of chastity, Artemis, she had turned her back on men and love. When the hunt was over he credited Atalanta with the honour of the kill, to the indignation of his uncles, the Thestiades. They believed the honour should be bestowed on their family only as Atalanta was an outsider. So enraged through his love for Atalanta, Meleager killed his uncles in cold blood. When his mother discovered this she retrieved the fateful log and burned it on the spit the boar was being roasted on. Meleager died an agonising death. Overcome by extreme guilt, Althaea ran into the forest and hung herself.

name: Deianira
notes: Sister of Meleager who wanted Heracles to join his bloodline, so he persuaded him to marry her. She lived a happy life married to Heracles but was tricked by Nessus, the centaur who survived the fight with Heracles into giving him his blood stained shirt. The blood was that of Hydra, and was deadly posionous. After giving him the shirt he died the most agonising death and she killed herself as a result.

name: Iole
notes: Daughter of King Eurytus, he arranged an archery competition (he was Greece's finest bowman) to find a suitable man to claim his daughter's hand in marriage. Heracles, Eurytus' former pupil, tried to enter the competition but Eurytus refused saying that a man that killed his wife and children could not take his daughter's hand. Heracles stormed off promising revenge.

name: Iphitus
notes: Son of King Eurytus, he pleaded with him to let Heracles marry his sister. He visited Heracles after but became victim of one of Heracles' infamous fits of rage and was thrown from the city walls to his death.

name: Neleus
notes: King of Pylos. Heracles sought a penance from him after he killed Iphitus in a fit of rage. But Neleus was an old friend of Eurytus, Iphitus' father, and so refused him atonement. Heracles vowed revenge. He helped his brother, Pelias, set siege to Iolcos believing him to be the rightful heir to the throne. This led to Jason, of Golden Fleece fame, to be smuggled out of the city and set off a famous chain of events.

name: Xenoclea
notes: One of the Delphic oracles. She was the one who ordered Heracles to atone for his killing of Iphitus. He was ordered to become a slave to Queen Omphale of Lydia for three years, after which he would give all of his earnings to Eurytus in compensation.

name: Omphale
notes: Queen of Lydia, sole ruler since the death of her husband, the mountain king Tmolus. Heracles was ordered to be her slave for three years to atone for the killing of Iphitus. The two became lovers and had a son, Agelaus.

name: Agelaus
notes: Also known as Lamas, son of Omphale, Queen of Lydia, and Heracles, who was serving a penance as her slave for the killing of Iphitus.

name: Telamon
notes: Friend of Heracles, he helped him take revenge on Laomedon, King of Troy for refusing payment for one of his labours. He took Laomedon's daughter, Hesione, as his wife. Was also one of Jason's Argonauts and brought Heracles along with him.

name: Peleus
notes: Friend of Heracles, he helped him take revenge on Laomedon, King of Troy for refusing payment for one of his labours. He was also one of Jason's Argonauts and brought Heracles along with him.

name: Priam
notes: The youngest son of Laomedon, King of Troy, he was spared by Heracles who took revenge on his father for refusing payment for one of his labours. He would go on to succeed his father to become the legendary King of Troy during the Trojan war. In one of the most famous scenes in the Iliad, Priam is escorted to Achilles to beg for the return of his son's body, Hector, the mightiest Trojan soldier. "I have endured what no one on earth has ever done before ‚Äì I put my lips to the hands of the man who killed my son." Achilles relents and hands over the body agreeing to a temporary truce to allow for the proper funeral rights before the war commences. He is later killed during the sack of the city after the Greek forces infiltrate inside the wooden horse.

name: Ajax the Great
notes: One of the mightiest Greek heroes of the Trojan war. Also known as Telamonian Ajax after his father, to distinguish him from the other Ajax in the Trojan war, the son of Oileus, Ajax the Lesser. He famously duels with Hector, leader of the Trojan forces which culminates in a stalemate. Towards the end of the war he recovers Achilles body alongside Odysseus. Both stake claims to Achilles' magical armour (forged by Hephaestus) and in a competition to find the winner, Odysseus proves more eloquent and the armour is awarded to him. Ajax, unable to deal with the dishonour, falls upon his own sword.

name: Teucer
notes: Legendary bowman that fought alongside his half-brother Ajax the Great at Troy. He is the legendary founder of the city of Salamis on Cyprus but cannot return there after the war because he had failed to avenge Ajax's death.

name: Paris
notes: Prince of Troy and son of King Priam and Queen Hecuba. He is famously asked to judge a beauty contest between Hera, Athena and Aphrodite by Zeus, in one of the first cases of managerial delegation. Aphrodite promises Paris the love of the most beautiful woman on Earth, Helen of Sparta, so he chooses Aphrodite. Helen was already married to King Menelaus of Sparta, so Paris had to abduct her. This 'Judgement of Paris' starts the Trojan war as the Greeks were duty bound to protect her and set sail for Troy to bring her back. He is not as active in the conflict, preferring to let his mighty warrior brother, Hector, do the bulk of the fighting, but he kills the mighty Achilles towards the end of the war, fatally wounded him in the heel. He himself is mortally wounded by Philoctetes later in the conflict and dies from his wounds.

name: Eurytus
notes: Conjoined twin brother of Cteatus. They were hired by Augeas to battle Heracles who sought revenge because he refused payment for one of his labours. They killed Heracles' own brother Iphicles, which roused Heracles into such a fury that he split them apart with a single swing of his sword.

name: Cteatus
notes: Conjoined twin brother of Eurytus. They were hired by Augeas to battle Heracles who sought revenge because he refused payment for one of his labours. They killed Heracles' own brother Iphicles, which roused Heracles into such a fury that he split them apart with a single swing of his sword.

name: Molione
notes: nan

name: Actor
notes: nan

name: Nestor
notes: Took over his father's (Neleus) throne after Heracles took revenge on him for not atoneing him of the killing of Iphitus. He would become one of the wisest kings in the history of the Greek world, famed for his sound judgement and his distinguished service in the quest for the golden fleece and as a brave ally of Agamemnon in the Trojan war. He also took part in the hunt for the Calydonian Boar. Atalanta saved his life when she fired an arrow at the boar just as he was about to be gored.

name: Hippoco√∂n
notes: King of Sparta, he aided his friend Neleus during his battle with Heracles. Heracles took revenge by killing him and his sons and installing his older brother Tyndareus, the rightful King of Sparta who Hippoco√∂n had ousted, on the throne. This would cause devestating consequences in the upcoming Trojan war.

name: Alcyoneus
notes: Stole Helios' cattle which kickstarted the Gigantomachy - the war of the Giants. He scaled Olympus and tried to rape Hera but Heracles arrived just in time to stop him. He buried him under Vesuvius where he grumbles to this day.

name: Achelous
notes: River god who tried to woo Deianira. Heracles had promised her brother Meleager that he would be the one to marry her so he wrestled him into submission breaking one of his horns in the process. To get it back, Achelous offered in exchange the fabled Horn of Plenty, or Cornucopia.

name: Hyllus
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, would go on to form an army that would defeat the tyrannical Eurystheus, the man who sent their father on his twelve labours.

name: Glenus
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, would go on to form an army that would defeat the tyrannical Eurystheus, the man who sent their father on his twelve labours.

name: Ctesippus
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, would go on to form an army that would defeat the tyrannical Eurystheus, the man who sent their father on his twelve labours.

name: Onites
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, would go on to form an army that would defeat the tyrannical Eurystheus, the man who sent their father on his twelve labours.

name: Macaria
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, would go on to form an army that would defeat the tyrannical Eurystheus, the man who sent their father on his twelve labours.

name: Oeneus
notes: Father-in-law to Heracles, during a feast Heracles killed his cupbearer for spilling wine on him. He was the King of Calydon, it was his excessive worship of the god Dionysus that so enraged Artemis which caused her to send the Calydonian Boar to terrorise his kingdom. He sent out a call for someone to kill the beast who would go down as 'the greatest hero of the age'. That hero was Atalanta.

name: Ceyx
notes: King of Trachis.

name: Alcyone
notes: Queen of Trachis.

name: Lichas
notes: Heracles' servant. He helped him into the shirt poisoned by Hydra's blood which was given to Heracles' wife Deianira by Nessus for revenge on Heracles killing the centaurs. He was killed as Heracles thrashed about in agony as the posion took hold.

name: Philoctetes
notes: Friend of Heracles. As Heracles was dying from the poisoned shirt mistakenly given to him by his wife Deianira, who was tricked by Nessus, the centaur, he lit the funeral pyre that Heracles constructed to end his pain. He was also one of Jason's Argonauts and a member of the Greek forces in the Trojan war.

name: Hebe
notes: Hera's cupbearer she bestowed her hand to Heracles upon his death to be his eternal wife.

name: Atreus
notes: The Heraclides, children of Heracles, installed Atreus on the deposed Eurystheus' throne.

name: Bellerophon
notes: Tamed the winged horse Pegasus, from which point on they would never be separated. Accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. He sought penance with King Proetus of Mycenae whose wife, Stheneboea, forced herself on Bellerophon but he refused her charms and insulted her in the process. He was sent to Iobates with a sealed letter detailing the false allegations. Iobates decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera. He managed to defeat Chimera with an arrow of lead which melted inside Chimera's body after she breathed fire. He was sent on more and more dangerous missions until he realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along. He was confronted by the citizens of Iobates' kingdom and without Pegasus, he was unable to defend himself. He prayed to his father Poseidon who flooded the local river Xanthus to show them that he was protected by the gods. When Iobates saw this he realised the letter must be false. He cleared up the whole mess and even married his daughter, Philono√´. When Stheneboea heard about the marriage she realised her deceit had been uncovered and she hung herself. Bellerophon grew into quite an arrogant and vain man. One day he flew with Pegasus to Olympus believing that he'd be welcomed due to his divine parentage. Zeus punished his hubris by striking Pegasus with a gadfly. Bellerophon landed on the rocks below and crushed his hip, Pegasus was kept on Olympus by Zeus to carry his thunderbolts. Bellerophon lived out his final days as a crippled, bitter and lonely man.

name: Glaucus
notes: King of Corinth, father, or step-father (Posedion being the father, we don't know for sure), of Bellerophon.

name: Deliades
notes: Brother or step-brother of Bellerophon. He was accidentally killed by Bellerophon during a hunting trip.

name: Polyidus
notes: Priest and seer who told Bellerophon to ask Athena's help to tame Pegasus.

name: Pittheus
notes: King of Troezen, a small city state in the Peloponnese. His daughter was engaged to the hero Bellerophon until he accidentally killed his brother Deliades during a hunting trip.

name: Aethra
notes: Was engaged to the hero Bellerophon until he accidentally killed his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. She was the mother of the hero Theseus. When Theseus kidnapped Helen, the Dioscuri took Helen back and kidnapped Aethra in revenge where she was taken to Troy to become Helen's handmaid. She was liberated when the siege of Troy finally ended.

name: Proetus
notes: King of Mycenae. Bellerophon sought penance at his palace for the accidental blood killing of his brother, Deliades, during a hunting trip. His wife, Stheneboea, had forced herself on Bellerophon but he had turned her down and insulted her in the process. She then tricked Proetus into thinking it was Bellerophon who had forced himself on her. He was in a quandry because refusing Bellerophon xenia, or hospitality, was also an affront to the gods. So he came up with the cunning plan of sending him to Lycia to see his brother-in-law, Iobates, with a sealed letter detailing the alleged crime.

name: Stheneboea
notes: Queen of Mycenae. She forced herself on Bellerophon whilst he was staying at their palace. Bellerophon refused her charms and insulted her in the process, claiming she wasn't attractive enough. She took revenge by claiming it was Bellerophon who had forced himself on her. Years later when she heard that her deceit had been uncovered, she hung herself.

name: Iobates
notes: King of Lycia. Bellerophon was sent to him with a sealed letter which detailed the false allegation by Stheneboea that Bellerophon had forced himself on her. After opening the letter he decided to get rid of Bellerophon by getting him to kill Chimera, the two-headed monster. When he managed the heroic feat he sent him on more and more dangerous missions which culminated in him ordering his own citizens to take up arms against him. When Bellerophon realised that Iobates had meant him harm all along he prayed to his father Poseidon to help him. Poseidon flooded the local river Xanthus to prove that Bellerophon was protected by the gods. Iobates realised the letter must be false and the whole mess was cleared up.

name: Philono√´
notes: Daughter of Iobates, who sent Bellerophon to kill Chimera. She eventually married Bellerophon when the allegations against him were proven false.

name: Solymus
notes: King of Pisidia. Married his sister, Milye. Their descendants, the Solymi, were a bane on Iobates kingdom so he sent Bellerophon and Pegasus to defeat them.

name: Milye
notes: Queen of Pisidia. Married her brother, Solymus. Their descendants, the Solymi, were a bane on Iobates kingdom so he sent Bellerophon and Pegasus to defeat them.

name: Cheimarrhus
notes: A fearsome pirate who hounded Iobates kingdom. Iobates sent Bellerophon to kill him.

name: Oeagrus
notes: Thracian King. Father or step-father of Orpheus.

name: Eurydice
notes: Wife of Orpheus. She was a reward for Orpheus' bravery and loyalty during the quest for the Golden Fleece. She was pursued by Aristaeus but she escaped and fell into a ditch where she was bitten and killed by an adder.

name: Hymen
notes: Minor deity of song, he gave us the word hymn. He was one of the Erotes, responsible for weddings and the marriage bed. He failed to bless the marriage of Eurydice and Orpheus.

name: Jason
notes: Smuggled out of Iolcos when he was a baby due to Pelias and Neleus laying siege to the city believeing they were the rightful heirs to the throne and not his father, Aeson. He was brought up by his mother's (Alcimede) friend, the great centaur, Chiron. Met Bellerophon, who was seeking help from Chiron for Pegasus burned skin at the hands of Chimera. He filled his head with heroic feats which influenced Jason in his formative years. When his tutelage with Chiron was finished he ventured back to Iolcos. On the journey he lost a sandal helping an old lady (Hera in disguise) across a river. It was prophecised to Pelias to beware of a man arriving from the country with one sandal so when he arrived in Iolcos, Pelias knew immediately who he was. Pelias agreed to let him take the throne but lied to him, telling him the land was cursed and that the only way to lift the curse was to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He arranged a mighty ship, the Argo, and a great crew, the Argonauts, to sail to Colchis and retrieve the fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis, King Ae√´tes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece. He managed these feats thanks to his new lover, Medea, whom Hera had had Eros strike her with his cupid's arrow. They escaped with the fleece back to Pelias where they realised he was never going to give up the throne so Medea tricked his nine daughters into killing him, believing they were being taught a magic trick and would be brought back to life. They had to flee Iolcos after this blood killing and sought refuge in Corinth. Here Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea, so enraged at this betrayal after everything she had done for him killed Creusa and her father, King Creon. In a terrible denouement she even killed her children. A broken Jason lived on Corinth until his old friend Peleus persuaded him to return to Iolcos and overthrow Acastus, the King. They managed this and he was finally on the throne of Iolcos. This didn't last long however as one day, asleep under the Argo, a rotten beam fell on him and killed him. It was an ironic twist as he was warned years before during the voyage to repair the damage caused during the crossing of the Bosporus, but who knew this would be the deadly outcome.

name: Bisaltes
notes: Founder hero of the Bisaltae peoples of Thrace.

name: Theophane
notes: She caught the eye of Poseidon who took her to the island of Crinissa where he turned himself into a ram and Theophane into a ewe. She gave birth to a golden ram.

name: Learchus
notes: Son of Athamas and Ino. Ino wanted them to take the throne of Boetia and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle so she contrived a famine and told Athamas that he must sacrifice Phrixus to end it. Athamas eventually found out and killed Learchus in the ensuing frenzy.

name: Melicertes
notes: Son of Athamas and Ino. Ino wanted them to take the throne of Boetia and not her step-children Phrixus and Helle so she contrived a famine and told Athamas that he must sacrifice Phrixus to end it. Athamas eventually found out and killed his brother Learchus in the ensuing frenzy. Ino and Melicertes were cornered and threw themselves over the cliffs in despair. Dionysus, ever grateful to his foster-mother Ino, transformed Melicertes into Palaemon, a dolphin-riding deity and guardian of ships.

name: Golden Ram
notes: Nephele sent the Golden Ram to rescue her children Phrixus and Helle from being sacrificed. Helle was killed when she fell from the ram but Phrixus survived and sacrificed the ram to Zeus and presented Ae√´tes, King of Colchis, where Phrixus sought refuge, with its golden fleece. Zeus, pleased with the offering, raised the noble creature to the firmament as Aries, the Ram.

name: Ae√´tes
notes: King of Colchis. It was here that Phrixus landed after being rescued by the Golden Ram. Phrixus presented Ae√´tes with the ram's golden fleece. When the Argonauts arrived at Colchis to claim the fleece, Ae√´tes demanded three tests of Jason before he could take it. To tame the fire breathing bulls, the Khalkotauroi, to sow some dragon's teeth from Cadmus and defeat the army that sprouts from the ground, and to kill the dragon that guards the fleece.

name: Perseis
notes: nan

name: Chalciope
notes: nan

name: Themisto
notes: Third wife of King Athamas of Boeotia.

name: Schoeneus
notes: Father of Atalanta, whom he abandoned when he saw his first born was a girl. He left her on a mountainside to perish.

name: Aeson
notes: Rightful heir to the throne of Iolcos but when his father, Cretheus, died, his half-brothers Pelias and Neleus laid siege to the city. Fearing the city was lost he smuggled out his first-born child, Jason. He was imprisoned by Pelias when the siege was lost. He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

name: Alcimede
notes: Mother of Jason, of Golden Fleece fame. Also known as Polymede. She died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

name: Promachus
notes: Son of Aeson and Alcimede and brother of Jason. He was born into captivity due to Pelias imprisoning his parents believeing he to be the rightful heir to the throne and not Aeson. He died whilst Jason was retrieving the Golden Fleece, possibly at the hands of Pelias, but we cannot be sure.

name: Sidero
notes: Second wife of Cretheus, King of Iolcos. She mistreated Cretheus' first wife, Tyro. When Cretheus died, Pelias, son of Tyro, laid siege to the city believing the throne should be his. He killed Sidero in revenge in a temple dedicated to Hera, thus incurring the wrath of the most vengeful of gods.

name: Argus
notes: Shipwright. Was commisioned by Jason to craft a vessel to help him the retrieve the Golden Fleece. The ship was named after its creator, the Argo.

name: Darnaus
notes: King of Argos.

name: Idmon
notes: A mortal seer and son of Apollo. He agreed to be one of Jason's Argonauts on the quest for the Golden Fleece. He foresaw fame but also an early death in the venture. He was gored to death by a boar in Mariandynia where the Argo had docked.

name: Tiphys
notes: Helmsman of the Argo and one of Jason's Argonauts. He succumbed to fever on the voyage.

name: Ancaeus
notes: King of Samos. Helsman of the Argo and one of Jason's Argonauts. He planted a vine before leaving for the voyage and prayed that it would harvest a beautiful vintage. The island's seer told him that he would return but he would never taste the vineyard's wine. Upon his return from the quest the vineyard had fluorished, Samos is now famous for its wine. He raised a cup of wine in a mocking fashion to the seer but was warned that "there's many a slip 'twixt cup and lip". Soon after he heard a commotion in the vineyard, a wild boar was destorying his grapes. He tried to subdue the boar but was gored to death in the process.

name: Hylas
notes: Beloved young page of Heracles. He joined him onboard the Argo on the quest for the Golden Fleece. He was taken by some water nymphs when the Argo was docked. A distraught Heracles abandoned the quest for the Golden Fleece and resumed his labours.

name: Polyphemus
notes: Not to be confused with the Cyclops of the same name, this Polyphemus was the brother-in-law of Heracles. He was also one of Jason's Argonauts. Was left ashore when the Argo sailed off without him. He and Heracles was looking for Hylas, Heracles' lover at the time. Polyphemus would go on to establish the city of Cius on the Bithynian coast.

name: Laomene
notes: nan

name: Calais
notes: Son of Boreas, the North Wind. Endowed with the ability to fly. Was one of Jason's Argonauts. He refused to go back and pick up Heracles, Polyphemus and Hylas when they inadvertently left them ashore (Hylas was lost, and Heracles and Polyphemus were searching for him). Heracles friend Telamon never forgot this and told Heracles years later. Heracles took his revenge by killing them. He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

name: Zetes
notes: Son of Boreas, the North Wind. Endowed with the ability to fly. Was one of Jason's Argonauts. He refused to go back and pick up Heracles, Polyphemus and Hylas when they inadvertently left them ashore (Hylas was lost, and Heracles and Polyphemus were searching for him). Heracles friend Telamon never forgot this and told Heracles years later. Heracles took his revenge by killing them. He constructed two pillars to mark their graves on the island of Tenos which were said to sway whenever the North Wind blew.

name: Euphemus
notes: Son of Poseidon, he could walk on water. He was one of Jason's Argonauts.

name: Aeolus
notes: Divine keeper of the winds. He kept the violent storm winds locked safely in his floating island of Aeolia, releasing them only at the command of the gods. Helped the Argo on its way on the quest for the Golden Fleece.

name: Hypsipyle
notes: Queen of Lemnos. Her people neglected the god Aphrodite so she made all the women smell so foul that the men wouldn't touch them and only married women from other islands. The women murdered all of the men on the island in revenge. The Argo anchored here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. The curse by that time was lifted and Hypsipyle and Jason got together and had twin sons, Euneus and Thoas. When Jason left to continue his quest, word had gotten out that Hysipyle had spared her father, Thoas, from the massacre of the menfolk. She escaped with her sons where they were captured by pirates and sold as slaves to King Lycurgus of Nemea.

name: Thoas
notes: Father of Queen Hypsipyle. She spared him when the women killed all of the menfolk on the island of Lemnos due to a curse put on them by Aphrodite. He found his way to Tauris on the Crimean peninsula where he was to play a part in the Trojan war.

name: Euneus
notes: Son of Jason and Hypsipyle.

name: Thoas
notes: Son of Jason and Hypsipyle.

name: Lycurgus
notes: King of Nemea. His slaves included Jason's wife Hypsipyle and his two sons who had fled the island of Lemnos and were captured by pirates.

name: Cyzicus
notes: King of Doliones, on the coast of the Sea of Marmara. The Argo berthed here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. After enjoying friendly hospitality they set sail but a storm blew them back to port. Being dark, the two peoples didn't recognise each other and fierce fighting broke out. The Argonauts killed the Dolionians including King Cyzicus.

name: Clite
notes: Queen of Doliones, on the coast of the Sea of Marmara. The Argo berthed here on the quest for the Golden Fleece. After enjoying friendly hospitality they set sail but a storm blew them back to port. Being dark, the two peoples didn't recognise each other and fierce fighting broke out. The Argonauts killed the Dolionians including King Cyzicus. When Queen Clite saw her dead husband she ran back into the palace and hanged herself.

name: Thrax
notes: A son of Ares, the god of war. His descendents were the fierce people of Thrace, modern day Bulgaria.

name: Glaucus
notes: Born a mortal fisherman in Boetia, but achieved divine status when he nibbled at a herb that he had observed to have the power to bring dead fish back to life. This gave him immortaility but caused him to grow fins and a fish's tail. From then on he was to be the patron god of fisherman, acting as guide to stricken sailors. He ordered the Argo to continue on its quest without Heracles, who they had inadventently left behind whilst he was looking for his lover, Hylas.

name: Amycus
notes: King of Bebryces where the Argo docked on its quest for the Golden Fleece. He was defeated in a boxing match by one of the Argonauts, Polydeuces.

name: Phineus
notes: King of Salmydessus. He was cursed by the Harpies who would steal his food. He was gifted with prophecy, but he would give his gift away too easily, the Oracles were supposed to be a cryptic people, hence the curse. When the Argo docked in his kingdom he told them it was prophecised that Calais and Zetus, two of the Argonauts and sons of Boreas, the North Wind would save him from them. They duly obliged and a close run fight ensued until it was broken up by Iris, the rainbow goddess. She told the Harpies to leave Phineus alone and the curse was lifted. As a reward Phineus told the Argonauts how to navigate the dangerous straits of the Bosporus.

name: Aello
notes: Aello, or 'storm' was one of the Harpies, meaning snatcher, flying women with human faces and wings and talons of birds.

name: Ocypete
notes: Ocypete or 'swift of flight' was one of the Harpies, meaning snatcher, flying women with human faces and wings and talons of birds.

name: Podarge
notes: Podarge or 'flashing foot' was one of the Harpies, meaning snatcher, flying women with human faces and wings and talons of birds.

name: Iris
notes: Goddess of the rainbow and messenger to the Olympians. She was also the handmaiden and personal messenger to Hera, the Queen of Heaven.

name: Electra
notes: Oceanid mother of Iris, the rainbow goddess, and the Harpies.

name: Thaumas
notes: Old sea god who personified the wonders of the sea. Father to Iris, the rainbow goddess, and the Harpies.

name: Argos
notes: Son of Phrixus and Chalciope. They were expelled by their grandfather, Ae√´tes, for alledgedly plotting against him. They met the Argonauts during their escape. This was a fateful meeting because it was Phrixus who had gifted the Golden Fleece to Ae√´tes. He decided to join the Argonauts and retrieve the fleece.

name: Cytoros
notes: Son of Phrixus and Chalciope. They were expelled by their grandfather, Ae√´tes, for alledgedly plotting against him. They met the Argonauts during their escape. This was a fateful meeting because it was Phrixus who had gifted the Golden Fleece to Ae√´tes. He decided to join the Argonauts and retrieve the fleece.

name: Phrontis
notes: Son of Phrixus and Chalciope. They were expelled by their grandfather, Ae√´tes, for alledgedly plotting against him. They met the Argonauts during their escape. This was a fateful meeting because it was Phrixus who had gifted the Golden Fleece to Ae√´tes. He decided to join the Argonauts and retrieve the fleece.

name: Melas
notes: Son of Phrixus and Chalciope. They were expelled by their grandfather, Ae√´tes, for alledgedly plotting against him. They met the Argonauts during their escape. This was a fateful meeting because it was Phrixus who had gifted the Golden Fleece to Ae√´tes. He decided to join the Argonauts and retrieve the fleece.

name: Circe
notes: A sorceress from Aeaea. She was asked to perform the cleansing ritual of the Argonauts after Medea had killed her own brother to get away from her father Ae√´tes after retrieving the Golden Fleece. But when she found out the true horror of the crime she refused. Odysseus and his crew land on her island on their way back from Troy. Circe turns half of his men into swine and Odysseus goes to try and rescue them. With Hermes' help he takes a drug which makes him immune to Circe's magic. Circe finds this incredibly attractive and falls in love with him and releases his men. Odysseus will remain with her for one whole year before he is convinced to leave for home.

name: Idyia
notes: Queen of Colchis, wife of Ae√´tes.

name: Medea
notes: Follower of the goddess of magic, Hecate. Hera had her struck by Eros' arrow of love so she would fall in love with Jason and help him in his three tests to win the Golden Fleece. She made a lotion which made him fireproof and able to defeat the Khalkotauroi. She told him how to defeat the Spartoi, and she made a potion that put the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece to sleep. During the escape from Colchis she murdered her brother, Absyrtus, to prevent Ae√´tes, their father, from catching them. When they returned the fleece to Pelias and realised he was not going to hand over his reign, she tricked his nine daughters, the Peliades, into killing him up thinking they were going to bring him back to life with special herbs. She and Jason had to flee afterward, it was after all, a blood killing. Took refuge with Jason in Corinth where Jason fell for the King's daughter, Creusa. Medea killed her and the King in and even killed her own children in an extreme act of revenge. After she escaped to Athens and married the king, Aegeus. When the hero Theseus turned up in Athens, Medea conspired to have him killed by poisoning him, wanting her own son Medus to be heir to the throne. When Aegeus found out that Theseus was his son, he managed to stop him from drinking the poison just in time. Medea fled Athens never to return.

name: Absyrtus
notes: nan

name: The Khalkotauroi
notes: A pair of bulls with mouths and hoofs of bronze. They were the fire-breathing creation of Hephaestus, a gift to King Ae√´tus of Colchis. Ae√´tes demanded that Jason tame the bulls as one of his tests to win the Golden Fleece. He managed to do so with the help of his lover Medea and some magic lotion that made him impervious to their fiery breath.

name: Butes
notes: One of the Argonauts. He was a Sicilian King, recruited for his bee-keeping skills which helped the crew's rations taste better. He fell to the Sirens charm on the return voyage. The Sirens sang to entice sailors onto their rocky cliff home where they would feast on them. He was rescued from their grasp by Aphrodite who whisked him away to Marsala in his home kingdom of Sicily, a place now famous for its honey-sweet wine. They became lovers and they had a child, Eryx.

name: Eryx
notes: Son of Aphrodite and Butes he grew up to be one of the finest boxers of his generation, but not good enough to survive a fateful bout one day with Heracles.

name: Alcinous
notes: King of Scheria, modern day Corfu. Helped the Argonauts on their way when the docked there but a fleet from Colchis, who were chasing them, demanded they be returned along with the Golden Fleece. He also aided Odysseus when he washed up on the island after a storm at sea. He took care of him and gave him a ship to finally send him home to Ithaca.

name: Arete
notes: Queen of Scheria, modern day Corfu. Helped the Argonauts on their way when the docked there but a fleet from Colchis, who were chasing them, demanded they be returned along with the Golden Fleece. She also aided Odysseus when he was shipwrecked and washed up on the shore.

name: Talos
notes: Protector of Crete, he was a huge bronze man who flung waves at pirates to protect the island. He attacked the Argo on its return with the Golden Fleece but Pirithous pulled out his nail that held in his ichor, the blood that runs in the veins of the gods.

name: Alcimede
notes: nan

name: Antino√´
notes: nan

name: Asteropeia
notes: nan

name: Evadne
notes: nan

name: Hippotho√´
notes: nan

name: Pelias
notes: nan

name: Pelopia
notes: nan

name: Pisidice
notes: nan

name: Patroclus
notes: Beloved friend of the hero Achilles. It was Patroclus' death at the hands of Hector that brought Achilles back into the Trojan war and thus turned the tides in the Greek allies favour.

name: Hector
notes: Leader of the Trojan forces in the Trojan war. He killed Achilles' beloved friend Patroclus before the walls of Troy. This brought Achilles back into the conflict and he eventually killed Hector in revenge. Achilles takes away the corpse and mistreats it, unable to find any resolution to his resentment. King Priam, Hector's father, visited Achilles to beg for the return of his son's body as described in one of the most famous passages in the Iliad.

name: Acastus
notes: Son of Pelias who sent Jason to retrieve the Golden Fleece. He was possibly one of the Argonauts, sent by his father as a mole to ensure either that the quest would fail, or the fleece would be returned to him. Took over the rule of Iolcos and not Jason after Medea had tricked Pelias' daughters into killing him.

name: Calydonian Boar
notes: Killed Ancaeus in his vineyard when he returned from the quest for the Golden Fleece.

name: Creon
notes: King of Corinth, he offered refuge to Jason and Medea who were fleeing Iolcos after the killing of King Pelias. When Jason fell for his daughter, Creusa, Medea posioned her and Creon died too when he tried to save her.

name: Thessalus
notes: Son of Jason and Medea. When Jason fell for Creusa, Medea would kill her children in revenge, but Thessalus was way being tutored by Chiron and survived. He would return to rule over Iolcos and Greater Aeolia, which we now call Thessaly in his honour.

name: Mermerus
notes: Son of Jason and Medea. When Jason fell for Creusa, Medea killed him in an act of revenge.

name: Pheres
notes: Son of Jason and Medea. When Jason fell for Creusa, Medea killed him in an act of revenge.

name: Creusa
notes: Daughter of King Creon of Corinth. Jason fell for her whilst taking refuge there. Medea poisoned her in revenge.

name: Atalanta
notes: Abandoned by her father Schoeneues because he wanted a boy and heir. She was left on Mount Parthenion to die, but she was discovered by a she-bear who had just lost her cubs, so instead of eating her, she raised her. She was taken in by a group of hunters later who named her Atalanta, meaning "equal in weight", i.e. she was man's equal. She quickly learned and surpassed her teachers in the skills of hunting and dedicated herself to the Olympian Artemis, goddess of chastity and hunting. She joined the hunt for the Calydonian Boar to prove herself the greatest hero of the age. After she had killed the boar she was taken back in her father, certainly not the last time a  parent was to reclaim a famous and successful child. He wanted her to marry to keep the kingdom in the family but being a disciple of Artemis she refused. "I will only marry a man who can best me in a foot race" she said. Being the fastest in the land she knew this was an impossible task. Hippomenes was the one who finally beat her in a race, thanks to Aphrodite's help. They were married soon after but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

name: Clymene
notes: Mother of the hero Atalanta, descendant of the royal Minyad clan of Boetia.

name: Althaea
notes: Queen of Calydonia, she fell into a deep sleep after giving birth to her son, Meleager, who was probably the son of the god of war, Ares. She dreamed that the Moirai, or Fates, had decided that his life would be noble, potentially being the son of Ares and all, but his life would only last as long as the central log in the fireplace by which his mother slept remained unburned. "Meleager's life will end in a flash, when his log of fate is turned to ash" they chanted. When she awoke she buried the log deep in the palace just to be safe. During the hunt for the Calydonian Boar, Meleager credited Atalanta with the kill. This enraged his uncles, the Thestiades (brothers of Althaea) who believed the honour should be bestowed upon their family only because Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, deeply in love with Atalanta, couldn't bear this so he murdered all of them. When Althaea found out she rushed to the palace and retrieved the fateful log which she burned on the spit the boar was being roasted on. Meleager died in agony. Distraught at her actions she ran into the forest and hung herself.

name: Thestios
notes: nan

name: Hypermnestra
notes: nan

name: Gorge
notes: nan

name: Melanippe
notes: Sister of Meleager, they were transformed into guinea fowl by Artemis after Meleager died to cluck and mourn their brother for eternity.

name: Eurymede
notes: Sister of Meleager, they were transformed into guinea fowl by Artemis after Meleager died to cluck and mourn their brother for eternity.

name: Mothone
notes: Sister of Meleager, they were transformed into guinea fowl by Artemis after Meleager died to cluck and mourn their brother for eternity.

name: Perimede
notes: Sister of Meleager, they were transformed into guinea fowl by Artemis after Meleager died to cluck and mourn their brother for eternity.

name: Toxeus
notes: Member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar alongside Atalanta. Refused to let Meleager credit Atalanta with the boar's hide when the hunt was won, they believed the honour should be bestowed on their family alone as Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, who was deeply in love with Atalanta, killed him.

name: Evippus
notes: Member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar alongside Atalanta. Refused to let Meleager credit Atalanta with the boar's hide when the hunt was won, they believed the honour should be bestowed on their family alone as Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, who was deeply in love with Atalanta, killed him.

name: Plexippus
notes: Member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar alongside Atalanta. Refused to let Meleager credit Atalanta with the boar's hide when the hunt was won, they believed the honour should be bestowed on their family alone as Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, who was deeply in love with Atalanta, killed him.

name: Eurypylus
notes: Member of the hunt for the Calydonian Boar alongside Atalanta.
