Refused to let Meleager credit Atalanta with the boar's hide when the hunt was won, they believed the honour should be bestowed on their family alone as Atalanta was an outsider. Meleager, who was deeply in love with Atalanta, killed him.

name: Cleopatra
notes: nan

name: Idas
notes: nan

name: Marpessa
notes: nan

name: Hyleus
notes: Died during the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

name: Hippasus
notes: Died during the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

name: Enaesimus
notes: Died during the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

name: Alcon
notes: Died during the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

name: Hippomenes
notes: Atalanta, forced to find a suitor by her father, had arranged a foot race where the winner would win her hand in marriage. Being a devoted disciple of Artemis, goddess of chastity she didn't want to marry, so a foot race, where she was the fastest person in the land, seemed the best compromise to her father. Hippomenes had fell in love with Atalanta whilst watching one of her races. He prayed to the goddess of love, Aphrodite, to be able to win Atalanta's heart. She bestowed upon him three golden apples which he used during the race to distract Atalanta and win the race. They were married but Hippomenes had failed to thank Aphrodite for her help and she cursed the couple into making love in a temple sacred to the goddess Cybele. So outraged was Cybele she transformed them into lions who the Greeks believed couldn't mate with each other. They lived out their lives drawing Cybele's chariot, closely coupled but denied the pleasure of sex for eternity.

name: Cybele
notes: A Phrygian deity associated with Artemis and Gaia.

name: Parthenopaeus
notes: Son of the hero Atalanta.

name: Labdacus
notes: Overthrown as ruler of Thebes by the twins Amphion and Zethus.

name: Laius
notes: Smuggled out of Thebes as an infant when his father, Labdacus, was overthrown by Amphion and Zethus. He reclaimed the throne later in life. He married Jocasta but found he was unable to father a child. He visited the Delphic oracle for advice who warned him that, "The son of Laius and Jocasta shall kill his father". He decided it best to abstain from the marriage bed until one day he got drunk and Jocasta became pregnant. He had the child imprisoned on the top of Mount Cithaeron.

name: Chrysippus
notes: Son of Pelops who was looking after Laius, the deposed infant heir to the throne of Thebes. Laius fell in love with Chrysippus and took him back with him to Thebes to reclaim the throne. This wasn't a consensual relationship and Chrysippus committed suicide in shame.

name: Jocasta
notes: Queen of Thebes. Her husband, King Laius had discarded their child, Oedipus, to avoid a prophecy which stated that his son would end up killing him. Oedipus was raised in Corinth but fate would have it that he would return to Thebes and he ended up marrying Jocasta after Laius had been killed. All of this was unbeknownst to the both of them. When a plague hit Thebes Oedipus sought the advice of the Delphic oracle where he was told that the plague would be lifted when the killer of Laius was named. Oedipus was the killer. He had gotten into a fight on the road years before and Laius was killed in the scuffle. Antimedes, Laius' servant and the only survivor of the fight was called by Oedipus to help find the killer. As soon as he saw Oedipus the truth came out about his real parents, his being abandoned by Jocasta and Laius and the fact that the prophecies had all come true, he had killed his father and slept with his mother. Jocasta ran away in anguish and hanged herself.

name: Antimedes
notes: Servant of Laius, King of Thebes. Antimedes imprisoned his son, Oedipus on top of Mount Cithaeron on Laius' orders, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him. He was part of Laius' entourage the day he encountered Oedipus on the road where a fight broke out and Oedipus had killed Laius, unbeknownst to him at the time was his father. Antimedes was the only one to escape unharmed. In later years Oedipus sent for Antimedes to try and find the killer of Laius which would lift the plague terrorising Thebes. When Antimedes set eyes on Oedipus he knew straight away he was the killer. He related the whole terrible story to him about the prophecies, being abandoned as a child, and the fact that he was the cause of the plague.

name: Phorbas
notes: Rescued the baby Oedipus from Mount Cithaeron after he'd been imprisoned at the top by his father, Laius, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him.

name: Straton
notes: Friend of Phorbas who rescued Oedipus. Straton took the baby to Corinth wher he was raised by the King and Queen, Polybus and Merope.

name: Polybus
notes: King of Corinth. Raised Oedipus after he was abandoned by his father, Laius, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him.

name: Merope
notes: Queen of Corinth. Raised Oedipus after he was abandoned by his father, Laius, who was trying to avoid a prophecy that his son would kill him.

name: Sphinx
notes: Head of a mortal woman, body of a lion and the wings of a bird. This fierce creature was sent by Hera as a curse on Thebes for King Laius for abducting Chrysippus. She stopped every traveller on the road to Thebes and forced them to answer a riddle. If they got it wrong they were thrown to their deaths on the rocks below. Oedipus was the hero to finally solve one of her riddles. "What walks on four feet in the morning, two at noon and three in the evening?". "Man" answered Oedipus. "He crawls on all fours at birth, upright on two legs during his prime, and uses a stick in old age". This sent the Sphinx crashing into the rocks below and the road was open again once again.

name: Eteocles
notes: Child of Jocasta and Oedipus, Jocasta's son and husband. Takes the throne of Thebes after Oedipus' demise. Initially agreeing to power share with his brother, Polynices, but refusing to give up the throne when it's his turn. Polynices raises an army to fight him (the so called Seven against Thebes) but they are both killed in the battle.

name: Polynices
notes: Child of Jocasta and Oedipus, Jocasta's son and husband. Agrees to power share Thebes with his brother, Eteocles, after the demise of Oedipus. But when Eteocles refuses to give Polynices his turn on the throne, Polynices raises an army (the so called Seven against Thebes) but both are killed in the battle.

name: Ismene
notes: Child of Jocasta and Oedipus, Jocasta's son and husband.

name: Euryganeia
notes: According to some versions of the Oedipus myth, Oedipus leaves Jocasta when the truth comes out and marries Euryganeia with whom he has his four children with.

name: Haemon
notes: nan

name: Eurydice
notes: nan

name: Theseus
notes: Theseus discovered his father was Aegeus, King of Athens. He wanted to enter Athens a hero to finally meet his father, so he set out along the dangerous coastal route from Troezen. During his travels he cleared the route of all evil, slaying monsters and murderes alike to enter Athens held aloft by an adoring public grateful to have the road made safe once more. Aegeus' wife, Jason's widow, Medea, was adamant that her own son, Medus, and not Theseus would be the heir to throne of Athens so she persuaded Aegeus, who didn't know it was his long lost son at this point, to order him to kill the Marathonian Bull. Theseus accomplished this heroic feat, inventing ancient bull fighting in the process. Medea then contrived to have him poisoned. Aegeus agreed, believing Theseus' fame was a threat to his rule. Just as Theseus was about to drink the poison, Aegeus noticed his sword. It was the exact same sword that he'd buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop him drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea fled Athens never to return. Theseus then went to Crete to lift the tributes that Athens had to pay. This was due to Aegeus sending Minos' (King of Crete) son Androgeus to kill the Marathonian Bull and getting killed. Minos threatened to raze Athens to the ground unless a tribute of seven maidens and seven youths were sent from Athens every year to feed the minotaur Asterion. Theseus sent himself as one of the sacrifical lambs where he fell in love with Minos' daughter, Ariadne. She gave him a ball of cotton which he used to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. He fled Crete with Ariadne to the island of Naxos. It was here that Theseus had a dream in which Dionysus warned him to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to him. He took the tough decision to leave her to save the Athenians he'd managed to save from being sacrificed to Asterion. He later took Antiope, an Amazon warrior as his queen kickstarting the Attic War, or Amazonomachy. They managed to defeat the Amazons but Antiope was killed in the process. He then had a sort of mid-life crisis, getting into all sorts of scrapes with his best friend Pirithous. They had the terrible idea one day of trying to kidnap Persephone, Queen of the underworld to be Pirithous' wife. Hades had them cast into stone chairs, their buttocks stuck to the seats. Heracles managed to free them during his twelfth labour to retrieve Cerberus. He married Phaedra, the younger sister of Ariadne. When visiting his son Hippolytus, Phaedra, Hippolytus' step-mother, was struck by a curse sent from Aphrodite in revenge for Hippolytus' neglect in all matters of love. Phaedra declared her love to Hippolytus but it wasn't reciprocated. Phaedra cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father Poseidon for justice. Hippolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra killed herself. Theseus was exiled from Athens for this unwitting role in the deaths of his son and wife. The end of his life was marked by shame and bitterness. He ended up as the guest of King Lycomedes of Skyros where one day he fell to his death over a cliff, pushed by Lycomedes but the reason is lost to us. His legacy wasn't tarnished however, Theseus goes down as one of the great heroes of Greek myth, and the greatest in all of Athens. His statue stands proudly in the centre of Athens today in Syntagma Square.

name: Aegeus
notes: King of Athens and father of the hero Theseus. Married to Jason's widow, Medea. Being a childless couple left a power vaccuum for the throne of Athens. Both Aegeus' brother, Pallas and Medea had designs on their children being the next king. When Theseus turned up he didn't recognise it was his son. Theseus being so popular was seen as a threat to Aegeus' rule so Medea hatched a plan to poison Theseus. Just as he was about to drink the poison he noticed Theseus' sword, it was the same one Aegeus himself had buried back in Troezen for his son to find one day. He managed to stop Theseus drinking the poison just in time and father and son were united. Medea had scarpered never to return. He angrily sent the boastful Androgeus, son of King Minos of Crete, to kill the Marathonian Bull. When Androgeus was killed, Minos demanded tribute or else he'd raze Athens to the ground. The tribute was to be seven maidens and seven youths sent every year from Athens to Crete to feed Asterion, the minotaur. Theseus joined the tribute and killed Asterion to lift the tribute and free Athenians from their terrible burden. Aegeus had told Theseus to use white sails on their return journey to indicate success. Theseus forgot and when Aegeus saw the black sails he threw himself to his death in the sea below in despair. The sea where this happened has been named after him ever since, the Aegean.

name: Periphetes
notes: The 'club man'. A cyclops who wielded a big club, robbing travellers on the coastal road to Athens. Killed by the hero Theseus.

name: Sinis Pityocamptes
notes: The 'pine bender'. He would tie travellers between two pine trees that he had bent down. He would then release the trees pulling the poor traveller apart. Killed by the hero Theseus.

name: Crommyonian Sow
notes: Either a large, aggressive wild pig, or a malicious and murderous old woman called Phaea who transformed into a pig. Killed by the hero Theseus.

name: Sciron
notes: A notorious outlaw who lurked along a set of cliffs above the Saronic Gulf. He liked to trick travellers into washing his feet on the edge of the cliffs only to kick them over the edge where a giant turtle would eat them at the bottom. Theseus encountered him on his heroic journey to Athens. He flung the bowl of hot water into Sciron's face just as he was about to wash his feet and pushed him over the edge to be eaten by the turtle.

name: Procrustes
notes: The 'stretcher'. He would take travellers into his guest house on the road to Athens where he would torture them on a bed that he could stretch. Theseus stayed at his house during his heroic travels. He could sense there was something macabre about the man so he played it cool and overheard him discussing with his wife the terrible plan he had in store for him. Theseus wrestled him to his own sick invention and gave him a taste of his own medicine. He then razed the place to the ground.

name: Phytalus
notes: Phytalus had once shown great kindess to Demeter, the goddess of the harvest. In recompense the goddess granted his descendants the power to expiate those who broke the laws of hospitality.

name: Pallas
notes: Brother of King Aegeus of Athens. As Aegeus was childless he expected one of his fifty sons, the Palliantidae, to take the throne. When Theseus, Aegeus's son, arrived in Athens, he was given the throne. The Palliantidae revolted but were killed by Theseus.

name: Medus
notes: Child of Jason's widow, Medea. She wanted him to assume the throne of Athens and not Theseus, King Aegeus' long lost son.

name: Androgeus
notes: Son of King Minos of Crete. King Aegeus of Athens had received Androgeus as a guest and foolishly sent him on a quest to kill the Marathonian Bull. Androgeus died in the attempt and Minos invaded Attica and threatened to burn the city to the ground unless he sent a tribute to Crete every year. The tribute was seven maidens and seven youths to be sent to feed the Minotaur Asterion which was kept in the labyrinth on Crete.

name: Leus
notes: Theseus' spy in the Palliantidae camp. He warned Theseus of their plan to assassinate him and claim the throne of Athens for themselves. Theseus was then able to defeat them.

name: Cecrops I
notes: The first king of Attica and ancestor of all Athenians. He judged in favour of Athena when she and Poseidon vied for control of the new town that he built. Hence the name Athens. His son is Daedalus, the inventor.

name: Perdix
notes: Nephew of Daedalus, the most gifted inventor in Greece. Perdix eventually outdid his uncle to become the better inventor. Daedalus threw him off the Acropolis in a jealous rage. Athena turned him into a partridge. This is why partridges always fly low and build their nests on the ground, as they never forget that terrifying plunge from the heights of Athens.

name: Asterion
notes: King of Crete and son of Minos, one of the judges of the underworld.

name: Ariadne
notes: Daughter of Minos and Pasiphae, king and queen of Crete. She fell in love with Theseus when he turned up at Crete to fight the minotaur Asterion and free Athens from its tribute to Crete (see Androgeus for more). She gave him a ball of thread to find his way through the labyrinth to kill Asterion. She fled with Theseus from Crete to Naxos where Theseus had a dream where he was warned to leave Ariadne on the island as she was betrothed to Dionysus. Theseus took the hard decision to leave her to save the rest of the Athenians who he'd saved from being given up to Asterion.

name: Icarus
notes: Son of Daedalus. He was imprisoned along with his father when Theseus killed the minotaur Asterion. Minos believed it must have been Daedalus that betrayed him. Being the inventor of the labyrinth that housed Asterion, only Daedalus could have helped Theseus through it. Whilst imprisoned in the tower at the top of the palace, Daedalus made wings from feathers and candle wax for them both to escape. Icarus though flew too high up and the wax melted his wings. He crashed into the sea and died. His body washed up on an island that is named after him today, Icaria.

name: Cocalus
notes: King of Camicus in southern Sicily. Daedalus the inventor worked for him after he escaped from Crete. Minos, King of Crete tracked him down eventually and demanded he be returned to him. Cocalus' daughters scalded Minos to death in the bath to prevent him from doing so.

name: Eurytion
notes: One of the centaurs, he tried to rape Hippodamia at her own wedding to Pirithous. Centaurs, unaccustomed to wine, had caused abominable scenes at the wedding, which Pirithous had only invited them to for political expediency. Pirithous and his best friend, the hero Theseus, fought back and the centaurs galloped away.

name: Caeneus
notes: Born a woman, Caenis, she was taken by Poseidon who offered her one wish. Taking no pleasure in being violated, she asked to be turned into a man to prevent it from ever happening again. Caeneus was present at the wedding of Pirithous and Hippodamia and fought the centaurs alongside Pirithous and Theseus where he was sadly killed.

name: Latreus
notes: A centaur who was present at the wedding of Hippodamia and Pirithous. He killed Canenus who was fighting on the side of Pirithous and Theseus, mocking him for once having been a woman.

name: Antiope
notes: Amazon warrior and wife of the hero Theseus. The Amazons didn't take kindly to one of their own being taken as a wife, being a fierce female band of warriors. Thus started the Amazonomachy, the war against the Amazons and Athens, also known as the Attic War. The Amazons were finally defeated at the battle on the Areopagus, the meeting place of the Athenian Council of Elders, also known as the Hill of Mars. Antiope was killed in the battle.

name: Molpadia
notes: Amazon warrior who fought in the Amazonomachy, the Attic War against Athens kickstarted when Antiope, an Amazon warrior, was taken by Theseus to be his bride. In the final battle on the Areopagus, Antiope was badly wounded, Molpadia put her out of her agony with a swift arrow through the neck. Theseus, seeing this, killed Molpadia.

name: Hippolytus
notes: Son of Theseus and the Amazon warrior Antiope. He devoted himself to hunting and became a disciple of Artemis. He turned his back on love which ignited the ire of Aphrodite. When his father and step-mother, Phaedra, visited, Aphrodite had Phaedra declare her love for Hippolytus. He rejected her advances and she cried rape to Theseus. Theseus prayed to his father Poseidon for justice who had him trampled to death by his chariot. Upon hearing this Phaedra took her own life.

name: Phaedra
notes: Wife of Theseus and younger sister of Ariadne, Theseus' first love. She was struck by Aphrodite's curse when visiting her step-son Hippolytus. This was in revenge for Hippolytus' dereliction of duty in praying to the goddess. The curse made her declare her love for Hippolytus, who rejected her advances. She cried rape to Theseus who prayed to his father, Poseidon, for justice. Hipolytus was trampled to death in a chariot "accident". Upon hearing this Phaedra took her own life.

name: Deucalion
notes: Inherited the rule of Crete after his father, King Minos, was boiled to death in Sicily chasing Daedalus.

name: Acamas
notes: Son of the hero Theseus and Phaedra.

name: Demophon
notes: Son of the hero Theseus and Phaedra.

name: Lycomedes
notes: King of Skyros. He looked after the hero Theseus at the end of his life until one day an argument broke out and he pushed Theseus to his death off a cliff.

name: Caucasian Eagle
notes: Sent by Zeus to tear out Prometheus' liver day after day for eternity. Slain by Heracles.

name: Seirenes
notes: Three monstrous sea-nymphs with bodies of birds and heads of women. They lured sailors to their deaths with bewitching songs. They were handmaidens to Persephone but when she was abducted by Hades, Demeter gave them the bodies of birds to go and find her. They gave up the search and settled on the island of Anthemoessa where they would sing their song of doom. Orpheus drowned out their music to give the Argo safe passage. They try to lure Odysseus on his return home to Ithaca but he ordered his men to tie him to the mast and block their ears with wax.

name: Deimos
notes: Son of Ares, the god of war. Along with his brother, Phobos, they accompanied their father into battle, driving his chariot and spreading fear in his wake.

name: Phobos
notes: Son of Ares, the god of war. Along with his brother, Deimos, they accompanied their father into battle, driving his chariot and spreading fear in his wake.

name: Ida
notes: One of the nymphs of Mount Ida on Crete who took care of the infant Zeus whilst he was hiding from his father, Kronos.

name: Adrasteia
notes: One of the nymphs of Mount Ida on Crete who took care of the infant Zeus whilst he was hiding from his father, Kronos.

name: Himalia
notes: Nymph of the island of Rhodes. Seduced by Zeus.

name: Metope
notes: Naiad nymph of the springs and streams of Stymphalus in Arcadia. Her waters were the source of the river Asopus, the river of her husband.

name: Sinope
notes: Daughter of the river god Asopus. She outwitted three gods, Zeus, Apollo and Halys, to preserve her virginity.

name: Halys
notes: nan

name: Carme
notes: A nymph and attendant of Artemis. Mother, by Zeus, of Britomartis.

name: Eubuleus
notes: nan

name: Britomartis
notes: Virgin goddess of hunting, fishing and fowling nets.

name: Ananke
notes: Primordial goddess of necessity, compulsion and inevitability.

name: Hydros
notes: God of the primordial waters.

name: Thebe
notes: nan

name: Taygete
notes: Pleiad star and mountain nymph of the Taygetos mountains in Laconia, southern Greece.

name: Telesto
notes: nan

name: Methone
notes: One of the nymph-daughters of one of the Gigantes, Alcyoneus. When Heracles killed Alcyoneus, they cast themselves into the sea in despair and were transformed into kingfishers by the goddess Amphitrite.

name: Pallene
notes: One of the nymph-daughters of one of the Gigantes, Alcyoneus. When Heracles killed Alcyoneus, they cast themselves into the sea in despair and were transformed into kingfishers by the goddess Amphitrite.

name: Anthe
notes: One of the nymph-daughters of one of the Gigantes, Alcyoneus. When Heracles killed Alcyoneus, they cast themselves into the sea in despair and were transformed into kingfishers by the goddess Amphitrite.

name: Despoena
notes: nan

name: Halimede
notes: nan

name: Psamathe
notes: nan

name: Sao
god_of: God of Safe Passage & the rescue of Sailors
notes: nan

name: Laomedeia
notes: nan

name: Neso
notes: nan

name: Aegisthus
notes: He was driven from the throne of Mycenae by Agamemnon. Whilst Agamemnon was laying siege to Troy, he took his wife, Clytemnestra, as a lover. The couple killed Agamemnon upon his return from Troy. He was eventually killed by Agamemnon's son Orestes.

name: Orestes
notes: Son of Agamemnon, he returns to Mycenae to take revenge on Aegisthus for killing his father.

name: Ajax the Lesser
notes: Member of the Greek forces during the Trojan war. Called the 'lesser' to distinguish hum from Ajax the Great, son of Telamon. He was the leader of the Locrian forces, part of the Greek army during the Trojan war. After the taking of Troy, he raped Cassandra inside a temple dedicated to Athena. The Greeks made sacrifices to appease her but it was not enough. Athena persuaded Zeus to strike the Greek ships down as they departed for home and Ajax was swallowed up by the sea. This sinking starts of Odysseus' ten year journey home, as told by in the Odyssey by Homer.

name: Oileus
notes: King of Locris and father of Ajax the Lesser of Trojan war fame.

name: Antilochus
notes: Son of Nestor and member of the Greek forces in the Trojan war. He sacrifices himself to save his father during the war.

name: Calchas
notes: Member of the Greek forces in the Trojan war, he was skilled at interpreting omens from the gods. He prophesized the war would last ten years after seeing a snake eat nine sparrows before being turned to stone by Zeus. He interpreted the wrath of Apollo and informed Achilles that Agamemnon had to release Chryseis for the plague to stop sweeping through the Greek forces.

name: Thestor
notes: nan

name: Diomedes
notes: Member of the Greek forces during the Trojan war. He steps up after Achilles refuses to fight alongside Agamemnon, becoming the Trojan's most feared opponent in the war. He wounded Aeneas during a battle who was saved by his mother Aphrodite. Diomedes gave chase and pierced Aphrodite's hand with a spear. When he returns home after the war he finds his wife has been unfaithful, Aphrodite taking her revenge.

name: Tydeus
notes: Father of Diomedes, the famous warrior who fought in the Greek ranks at Troy. He was one of the Seven Against Thebes.

name: Helen
notes: The most beautiful woman in the world, so beautiful that her face launched a thousand ships. She was married to King Menelaus but was abducted by Paris of Troy after Aphrodite promised her to him in the Judgement of Paris. This started the Trojan war when the Greek allies set out to reclaim her. In the Iliad, Helen is described as mournful, regretting her choice and wishing to be reunited with Menelaus. When Paris was killed in action she is eventually reunited with Menelaus and returns to Sparta.

name: Menelaus
notes: Brother of Agamemnon, leader of the Greek armies during the Trojan war. He was a central character in the conflict. It was the flight of his wife, Helen, to Troy that started the conflict. At the end of the conflict he goes to kill Helen for her infidelity but finds he cannot do it when she supplicates herself at his feet. They return together back to Mycenae to continue their reign.

name: Idomeneus
notes: One of the leaders of the Greek armies during the Trojan war.

name: Aerope
notes: nan

name: Penelope
notes: Wife of Odysseus. She remains faithful to him for the entire twenty years of his absence (ten during the Trojan war, and ten making his way home) despite being bombarded by potential suitors wanting to claim Odysseus' throne and fortune. Her name is therefore traditionally associated with marital fidelty. She arranges a challenge for the suitors, whoever can string Odysseus' bow and shoot an arrow through twelve axe heads may have her hand in marriage. Knowing only Odysseus can do this, she is sure that this will delay the suitors. When an old beggar actually completes the challenge she is sceptical that it is Odysseus himself. When he proves it by telling her about the unique olive branch bed leg in their bedroom, she finally accepts it is him and Odysseus' homecoming is complete.

name: Telemachus
notes: Son of Odysseus and Penelope, he is a central character in Homer's Odyssey. Angered by the suitors besieging his birthright and hounding his mother he sets sail, with the aid of Athena, to find his father visiting the old commanders of the Greek forces to find out information on his whereabouts. Upon his father's return he helps him kill the suitors to complete his homecoming.

name: Peisistratus
notes: Son of Nestor, he accompanies Telemachus on his quest to find his father, Odysseus where they became close friends.

name: Aeneas
notes: Leader of the Dardanians, an ally of Troy during the Trojan war. Son of Anchises and Aphrodite, he manages to escape from Troy so that he might re-found "Troy in the west". He does. The city would go on to be called Rome after his ancestor Romulus. He is the protagonist of Virgil's Aeneid which tells the story of Aeneas' journey.

name: Anchises
notes: Father of Aeneas by the goddess Aphrodite.

name: Themiste
notes: nan

name: Capys
notes: nan

name: Andromache
notes: Wife of Hector, the greatest warrior in the Trojan army. When Troy was sacked and Hector killed she was married off to various victorious Greek soldiers. She ended up in Pergamum where she died of old age.

name: Antenor
notes: Advisor to Priam, King of Troy during the Trojan war.

name: Hecuba
notes: Queen of Troy, wife to Priam, King of Troy. Their offspring would feature heavily in the Trojan war.

name: Glaucus
notes: Member of the Trojan forces during the Trojan war. He fought a duel with Diomedes, who, upon learning Glaucus' ancestry (he was a grandson of the hero Bellerophon) refused to fight him on the grounds that his own grandfather, Oeneus, was a close friend of Bellerophon. They agreed not to fight and exchanged armour as a token of continued familial friendship. He was killed later in the conflict by Ajax the Great.

name: Hippolochus
notes: nan

name: Scamandrius
notes: nan

name: Laodice
notes: The most beautiful princess of Troy. She fell in love with Acamas, son of Theseus, who had come to Troy to try and recover Helen through diplomatic means. According to some sources, after the Trojan war, she prayed to the gods fearing she'd become a prisoner. She was then swallowed up in a chasm that opened in the earth, probably by Persephone, taken down to Hades.

name: Lycaon
notes: Member of the Trojan forces during the war. He was confronted by Achilles, bent on revenge after the killing of Patroclus. Lycaon grasped Achilles' knees and begged for mercy. None was forthcoming and Achilles' killed him on the spot.

name: Pandarus
notes: Skilled bowman of the Dardanians, allies of the Trojan forces during the Trojan war. He was tricked by Hera and Athena (who wanted Troy destroyed) into firing an arrow at Menelaus during a truce in the war. Menelaus, protected by the Hera and Athena, only suffered a minor injury, but the breaking of the truce restarted the conflict.

name: Oenone
notes: The first wife of Paris of Troy whom he abandons for Helen of Sparta. Helen visits her later in the war when Paris is wounded to beg her to heal him. Oenone refuses and according to some sources, kills herself in shame.

name: Kebren
notes: nan

name: Polydamas
notes: Friend of Hector and member of the Trojan forces in the Trojan war.

name: Panthous
notes: Advisor to Priam, King of Troy during the Trojan war.

name: Sarpedon
notes: One of the mightiest soldiers of the Trojan forces during the Trojan war. He was killed by Patroclus when he entered the battle wearing Achilles' armour. His father Zeus debated whether to spare his life but was reminded that he was fated to die and that would set a precedent for other gods to save their own offspring.

name: Laodamia
notes: Daughter of Bellerophon and Philonoe and mother of Sarpedon by Zeus.

name: Sarpedon
notes: Son of Zeus and Europa, brother to Minos and Rhadamanthus, who would go on to become judges of the underworld. He was banished by Minos and eventually established the kingdom of Lycia.

name: Theano
notes: A priestess of Athena in Troy. She advocated peace and pressed for Helen's return to the Greeks. Because of this she was spared when the city was sacked.

name: Cisseus
notes: Thracian king and father of Theano.

name: Telecleia
notes: Thracian queen and mother of Theano.

name: Eurydice
notes: Queen of Troy and wife of Ilos, founder of Ilium, the region in which Troy is located.

name: Penthesilea
notes: Amzonian queen, she fought alongside the Trojans during the Trojan war during which she was killed by Achilles.

name: Otrera
notes: Queen of the Amazons and consort of Ares whom with she gave birth to Hippolyta, Antiope, Melanippe and Penthesilea. She was the founder of the Temple of Artemis at Ephesus, one of the seven wonders of the ancient world.

name: Melanippe
notes: nan

name: Arcesius
notes: King of Ithaca and father of Laertes. Grandfather of the legendary hero Odysseus.

name: Icarius
notes: Spartan king and father of Penelope, Odysseus' wife.

name: Periboea
notes: Wife of Icarius whom with she had a daughter, Penelope, Odysseus' wife.

name: Eurycleia
notes: Nurse to Odysseus, and later, his son Telemachus. Eurycleia recognises Odysseus when he finally makes it back to Ithaca after twenty years away. Disguised as a beggar, Odysseus was bathed by Eurycleia who recognised a scar on his leg. He swore her to secrecy until the suitors could be killed. Eurycleia then informed Odysseus on which of the servants had been unfaithful to Penelope during his absence, who were later hanged.

name: Eumaeus
notes: Friend of Odysseus. Eumaeus is the first person Odysseus encounters when he finally makes it home to Ithaca. Odysseus is in disguise so Eumaeus doesn't recognise the stranger, but he treats him well, offering him food and shelter. Later he assists Odysseus and Telemachus in the killing of the suitors of Penelope.

name: Melantho
notes: One of Penelope's favourite maids but she betrays her by sleeping with the suitors of Penelope during Odysseus' long absence. When a disguised Odysseus finally returns home he is mocked by Melantho for being a beggar. After Odysseus kills the suitors, Melantho is ordered to clean the hall after which she is hanged by Telemachus.

name: Eurymachus
notes: A nobleman from Ithaca, he is one of the leading suitors of Penelope during Odysseus' long absence. Like the other sutors he shows no regard for Greek hospitality or the custom of courtship. He consumes all of Odysseus' food and drink and even arranges for Telemachus, Odysseus' and Penelope's son to be killed to get him out of the way. When Odysseus finally returns home Eurymachus tries to blame the other suitors whilst pleading for his life. Odysseus offers no clemency and he kills him with an arrow into his chest.

name: Antinous
notes: A nobleman from Ithaca, he is one of the leading suitors of Penelope during Odysseus' long absence. Like the other sutors he shows no regard for Greek hospitality or the custom of courtship. He consumes all of Odysseus' food and drink and even arranges for Telemachus, Odysseus' and Penelope's son to be killed to get him out of the way. When Odysseus finally returns home disguised as a beggar, Antinous assaults him with a chair, showing no respect for the lower classes. As such he is the first suitor to be killed when Odysseus finally reveals his true identity.

name: Briseis
notes: Taken by Achilles as a war prize during the Trojan war. They came to love each other dearly. Agamemnon then threatened to take her from Achilles as he was forced to release Chryseis, his own war prize. This is the dispute that lies at the heart of the plot of Homer's Iliad. She was later returned to Achilles by Agamemnon as he was desperate for Achilles to rejoin the war. She would remain with Achilles until his death.

name: Chryses
notes: Trojan priest of Apollo. Agamemnon took his daughter, Chryseis, as a war prize during the Trojan war and refused to give her up when Chryses tried to ransom her. This angered Apollo who sent a plague sweeping through the Greek armies and Agamemnon was forced to release her to end it.

name: Chryseis
notes: Taken by Agamemnon as a war prize during the Trojan war. Agamemnon refused to give her up when her father, Chryses, tried to ransom her. This angered Apollo who sent a plague sweeping through the Greek forces and Agamemnon was forced to return her to end it.

name: Clymene
notes: Handmaid of Helen in Troy.

name: Amphinomus
notes: Considered the best behaved suitor of Penelope, he tried to dissuade the other suitors from killing Telemachus. This did not stop him being killed along with the other suitors however.

name: Nausicaa
notes: She discovers the shipwrecked Odysseus on her island. She cares for him and takes him to her parents, King Alcinous and Queen Arete to look after him. Odysseus is provided with a ship to finally sail him home to Ithaca. As he sets sail Nausicaa tells Odysseus "Never forget me, for I gave you life".
